description:
Such amazing flavors!! Every single thing was so flavorful and tasty. I've never had Guamanian food before. I have been here a few times and always get their tasting menu. Each dish is not very big (duh, it's a tasting menu), but it's the perfect amount to leave me satisfied and full. Super interesting (but limited) wine selection as well.

The service and ambiance are great too. Never once did I have to ask for water, we got great explanations of the dishes, and it's a fun lively vibe inside.

THEY'RE CLOSING THOUGH :( Stupid SF raised the rent on them. My BF & I have joined their email list to see where they end up next, if they do pop ups, etc. Fingers crossed they come back soon!
author: Betty M.

description:
Disappointed!! I came with a friend who had visited Prubechu previously, and had such a phenomenal experience, that she wanted to return once more, before their closing at the end of September.  I was really excited, since she had  such a wonderful dine here previously.  Sadly, our visit this time, was one big disappointment.  

I surmise that our extreme lackluster experience may be due to their anticipated closing at the end of this month.  When my friend came here earlier this year, she was served good, generous portions of food.  Not at all the case this time.  Frankly, I think knowing they're closing altered their overall execution.  It is surprising though, given the fact that the waiter mentioned that the hope to relocate at a later date.  If that is indeed the case, I would think they would've made an effort to sustain the level of quality that earned them a good Yelp ratings to begin with.  Such a shame.   

We both ordered the Chef's tasting menu, for $65.  How they can justify the amount of food they serve for $65.00 is way beyond me. Very very small portions for mediocre food, which with taxes and tip, will cost you over $80.00.  Not at all justified for what we were served!  Bread, a couple of small appetizer size dishes, and the so-called "main" entree was a rice porridge dish with just a few diced pieces of meat, something better suited as a luncheon entree.  I was so dismayed when the waiter announced that that the so-called main entree was going to be our last savory dish, before the dessert.  Unbelievable, I thought, and I was right, as about three hours later, I was thinking we should have had a burrito at La Taqueria down the street instead.  I ended up snacking that night on some super delicious homemade soup given to me by wonderful friends, which saved me that night from going to bed hungry!  The highlight was the dessert, but that was literally a two bite item.  

This was my introduction to Guamanian cuisine, and probably my last, based on my experience here.  I'm wondering now if there's a reason why we don't see an influx of Guamanian restaurants all over the culturally cuisine diverse Bay Area.  I'm sure there's a mom or grandmother out there from Guam that makes delicious Guamanian food that I would just love, but she definitely wasn't in the kitchen at Prubechu!  

Setting was pretty loud, not exactly what I would describe as conducive to conversation.  It was also somewhat unpleasantly warm inside, probably because of the small size of the restaurant, and the open kitchen with the gas stoves and flames burning like crazy.  

Perhaps ordering a la carte entrees may have been the better way to go.  I was just so turned off by the whole experience, that I won't be giving them a second chance, even if they end up relocating.
author: Lori N.

description:
The place is really cute and had plenty of open seats when we showed up so we probably didn't even need a reservation.

Because we had 8 people, we could only get the 6 course tasting menu for $65 each. They didn't have a menu of the items because they're seasonal so they just explained each dish as it came out.

I've never had Guamian cuisine before so I was pretty excited to try this place. After all 6 dishes, I have to say my favorite was the dessert - coconut salted caramel ice cream. The ice cream had a lot of shredded coconut in it, which was a really interesting texture. The taste was extremely rich and probably the best salted caramel ice cream I've ever had in terms of flavor.

However the other dishes didn't really impress me. I found them lacking in terms of flavor complexity. They tasted overwhelmingly salty or acidic to me. My second favorite part of this meal was probably the lightly breaded egg in the porridge. 

I'm really glad that I tried the place, especially since I hear that it's closing soon. I am down to try more Guamian food but for now I have to say Prubechu looked better than it tasted.
author: Lily L.

description:
Alright I have too finish this review because it is unfortunately closing at it's current location.   And I'm hoping that it will open up somewhere else.  I've been here twice.   I've been holding back doing the review because I wanted to post the pictures with it but I might as well do it now.  

I have been there for a birthday and another time with old high school classmates and it might as well be a birthday since we treated the other people.  

But all times for a Guam person it is familiar food but made different and taken up a notch.  If anything it's always worth a try.  Both times we always did the Pres Fixe menu so I could try out different things and all the time it's always been really good. 

I do hope they come back.  

I did see that somebody was complaining about a dish and the price but I'm basically thinking that.  That's SF and again one of the reason's why it's closing its doors because the rent has finally gotten too much.
author: Homer S.

description:
Unpretentious, welcoming, and delightfully tasty.

Prubechu had me dreaming of taking a vacation to a beach where the water is clear and blue. Prubechu is living proof that trying new things definitely pays off.

To start off, the service was great. Everyone was friendly and everyone seemed to genuinely be proud of the food that was being served. You can tell these people really care. 

We did the tasting menu, so I'll just highlight a couple of the things we liked the most! For sure, my ultimate favorite was the corn soup. It was creamy, lots of sweet corn, spam, and crunchy onion bits. It also came at the perfect temperature--I like my soup barely cool enough to not scald my mouth. The last course: wild boar porridge with the fried egg was also amazing. We also liked the coconut candy ice cream that everyone seems to talk about. It had sooo many textures (in a good way).
author: Claire C.

description:
Similar to historic San Francisco, this charming place in the Mission districts holds much history to the little island of Guam. Inside you will find many cultural decor, books and artifacts paying homage to the island. 

My husband and I share many fond memories here and are very sad to see that they will no longer be around. We came here last Friday to have a final date night to ourselves and enjoy some great food, chill music and wonderful hospitality. Every visit here we had tried something different. A few of my all time favorites include:

1. Chamorro Empanada: Crispy on the outside, ooey gooey in the inside. Gotta have it with the Dinanche Aoli 

2. Shrimp Kelaguen with Tatiyas: Cause I cant find any other Chamorro restaurant that makes seafood kelaguen (this dish is usually made with chicken)

3. Shrimp Pancake: It was our first time having it this weekend and its very similar to Chamorro shrimp patties. Fluffy, tons of shrimp/peas/corn baked inside drizzed with the dinanche aoli on top and arugula. great to share between 2-3 people. 

4. Lastly, their Roasted Pig: In the past we've attended one of their roasted pig events and it was amazing! Hands down was the best lechon i've ever had in my entire existence. If only lechon was a regular menu item i would request for it every single time. 

Thank you to the wonderful staff of Prubechu for serving us. We wish you the very best on your next journey.
author: Rhea T.

description:
I understand restaurant business is hard in San Francisco. 

But charging $19 for a beef dish with this little beef is outrageous. It is an insult to the customer's intelligence. It should call it a noodle instead of beef. 

I sincerely question how many ratings on Yelp for this restaurant is legitimate.
author: Mimi Z.

description:
Very stylish place and friendly cooks and service workers

We had lunch and enjoyed it very much

Carmelized potato soup with spinach and fried onions 

Tinaktak
Mushrooms green beans ground beef noodles 

Learned about a bird native to Guam........ ko'ko'
author: Foodlover B.

description: Yuuuuuuum. Me and my husband had the pickled vegetables, the kelaguan gamson (octopus ceviche), tinaktok (noodles) and the shrimp pancake. Everything was amazing, but you have to get the kelaguan octopus - it's bomb and it comes with fresh tortillas.The service was also amazing!
author: Arika B.

description:
Per my review a year ago, I said I wanted to bring my bf. Last friday, I took my bf, now husband, and he loved it! I was able to book a same day reservation via yelp. Another wahoo!

We both got the $65 tasting menu and we were just blown away by the flavors and quality of the dishes. His favorite was the chicken sausage wrapped in banana leaf and my favorite was the homemade spam dish. I got the tasting menu last time I was there so I thought I would be disappointed, but I was even more impressed that I loved all the dishes I was served. I also very much love impressing my foodie husband because man, he can be picky sometimes!! He loved their beer selection too, especially the ones from Modern Times (brewery in San Diego) which he said he has never tried before. 

The service was outstanding. I am pregnant so they hard boiled my egg versus leaving it runny in the spam porridge dish. Very accommodating and they do ask if you have any allergies or issues prior to serving the tasting menu of 5 dishes + bread. The bread starter was yummy and the last course, a salted ice cream dessert was super tasty. A lot of tasting menus (much more expensive ones too) I've had before don't start or end this well. 

This place is truly a gem of San Francisco and I just found out that it is the only Bay Area eatery that serves Chamorro (island) food. Yay!!!! It's not the cheapest of dinners BUT it is very affordable for the quality of food you get! Get the tasting menu too!! You won't be sorry. One more yay for Prubechu!!
author: Cicely T.

description:
I really wanted to like this place.  But, most dishes were way too acidic for me.  It definitely triggered my acid reflux problem.  The tinaktak and the barbecue pork ribs were unbearably acidic.  But, the wonderful spices and how the meat and noodles were prepared showed great potentials of the talents in the kitchen.  Too bad the extremely high acid just killed it for me.

The service was very friendly and efficient.  Not sure whether we'll go back again.
author: TopCat W.

description:
Loved my experience at Prubechu! Getting to try Guamanian food was so fun -- this is not a cuisine you run into every day in the Bay Area!

I did the tasting menu with a group of 6. The experience was fantastic! As other reviews have mentioned, is true that an assemblage of a la carte items shared family style might be more affordable if cost is a concern, but I enjoyed the experience of trying the chef's selections. I also thought it was a great value at $65, since we were served 6 generously portioned courses. 

Everything we tried was flavorful and delicious. We had 5 savory courses and 1 dessert: the rolls served at the beginning were outstanding, as was the soup, rice porridge with perfectly cooked egg (breaded and crispy on the outside, soft boiled on the inside... So good!), and pork rib. Everything was comforting and satisfying. We were all stuffed at the end!

I loved the ambience of the restaurant as well; it's very cozy and casual, with an open kitchen where you can see the chef at work. 

The service was also excellent. Our servers were attentive, and did a great job explaining the courses to us and pacing the meal. They also called the day of to confirm if anyone in our party had dietary restrictions that should be accounted for in our tasting menu, which I thought was great. 

The wine and beer list was also great and reasonable, with most wines by the glass priced around $10. 

I'll definitely come back to do the tasting menu again or try the a la carte options.
author: Christine G.

description:
We loved loved loved everything about our dinin experience. The restaurant is owned and run by wonderful people from Guam, proud Chomorros and their heart, pride and humility is reflected in the  food. Simple ingredients, put together beautifully creating culinary alchemy. 
We didn't even know where Guam was on a map when we walked in and left learning so much about the country, it's history and its people thanks to one of the owners of the restaurant who was also serving us. 
The food isn't cheap but it never is in SF but truly worth it for the entire experience. Highly recommend trying it once.
author: Ashima S.

description:
Wanted to like this more than I did. After vacillating about doing the tasting menu or a la carte, we were persuaded into the former since it was our first foray into Guamanian. (Note: they count the bread as one of the 6 courses, which is a little irksome. Just call it a 5- course menu!) 

The courses were as follows:
-Bread and butter: good but basic
-Fried shrimp: served with aioli and escabeche-esque vegetables. The flavors were good, but I was disappointed at how soggy the shrimp batter was. No crunch. 
-Chicken sausage: cooked in a banana leaf and served with a cream sauce and fried onions. Again, this was good, but not anything memorable. 
-Rice porridge: with coconut milk, mushrooms, spam, and a whole egg fried Scotch-egg style. This was the standout dish. Really great flavor, and that egg was deliciously crispy and yolky. I didn't love the mushrooms as I don't think they melded well with the rest of it, but I still ate my bowl clean. 
-Poached cod: with broccolini and potato. Fine but not very memorable. 
-Coconut candy ice cream: wayyy too sweet for my liking, but has a slightly burnt taste at the end. I thought it was interesting but just not my thing. 

In addition, we got the red rice with smoked meats. I felt that all the meat (pork shoulder and belly) was pretty tough. The rice was good though!

And I would say overall the service was great. It's clear the owner cares about the food and his customers. I would almost bump to 4, but spending $90 each for a so-so meal makes me hesitant to really recommend this one.
author: Gwen H.

description: San Francisco, especially the Mission district, is known for great restaurants, but this place is over the top. I can't believe they are closing because of their landlord. I will follow them wherever they go and you should too
author: Rosalie J.

description:
Never had Guamanian food before so wasn't sure what to expect, but everything we ordered was tasty!

Empanada - Filled with veggies in what tastes me me like a veggie samosa.  Crust was good and crispy.  Aioli was delicious. 

BBQ Pork Ribs - came with 2 small ribs.  Good smoky flavor, but it wasn't fall off the bones and not super easy to eat.  

Gollai Hagon Suni - It was pretty much squash and spinach in a coconut curry sauce.  It had good flavor, but it's definitely not enough as an entree.  There's no carbs or anything filling in this dish. 

Kelaguen Manok (chicken ceviche) - this was probably my favorite.  Chicken is bbq'd dry and was flavorful with lemon zest, which offered a more refreshing taste.  I liked making my own little wraps with the coconut flatbread and spicy aioli.  I kinda wish there were some veggies in here as that would have balanced out my wrap better. 

Tinaktak - Imagine beef stroganoff...but sour.  That's what it tasted like to me.  It was interesting...I wasn't sure if I liked it or indifferent, but definitely didn't dislike it!

We also got sticky rice wrapped in a banana leaf with kiwi and some sort of cream sauce.  It was good because it wasn't too sweet.  

Overall, it was a really good meal.  Got to try something I haven't tried before and enjoy good company.  Service was also great.
author: Jenny L.

description: Went here a couple weeks ago.   I remember the food being good, but none of the courses really stood out.    I'd go back.
author: Michael E.

description: Went here with some friends for dinner and came back today for lunch. Very casual, intimate vibe both times. The staff are laid back but attentive. It was my first time trying Guamanian food and I was not let down. The flavors were really savory, but not overtly so. I ordered the tinaktak and my friends got the kelaguen manok. Both were superb. I did wish the portions were a bit bigger, but with dessert I definitely left feeling full. I love that this place doesn't seem to get too busy -- it keeps the atmosphere feeling island-y... or maybe that's just the music? Also love how close to BART it is. Super convenient.
author: Tiffany S.

description:
As a local of Guam, I needed to check out Prubechu while I was in SF, and I was not disappointed! Experiencing an elevated take on Chamorro food was definitely refreshing and unexpected. 

I didn't do the tasting menu, but recommend that if you are new to Chamorro food and want to try a bit of everything. 

I started with the potato soup, which was probably my favorite thing on the menu. It is so unassuming but DELISH with the coconut milk. You only need one to share though - it's large! 

Next, I got the tinaktak, which is served (untraditionally) with ramen noodles and I didn't hate it ...might start using noodles instead of rice when I go back to Guam. 

I also got the local fish (flown from Guam) and the shrimp keleguen, which was pretty spicy!

Needless to say, I ended up taking home leftovers, but it was so worth it! I only wish I lived closer, so I could go more often.
author: Sirena L.

description:
Soooo Goooood!
I am Guamanian and everything we ordered was delicious!
They have all the traditional dishes and some with new twists.
It is Island Style so please keep in mind, good food takes time. Don't come here if you are in a rush.
We ordered:
-To start, Empanada (Get 1 per guest. You're not gonna want to share)
-Red Rice (platter) comes with meat and veggies
-BBQ Pork Ribs
-Kelaguen Manok (chicken ceviche) eat it with the tortillas
-Tinaktak (twist) they serve it with noodles instead of rice...aaaand I'm gonna make it like that at home now!
-Coconut Candy Ice Cream for dessert
There was 3 of us and we had plenty to eat with a good amount of food to take home...and yesss you are going to want to take some home. 

Definitely coming back! 
I am going to order the Chef's Tasting Menu next time.

Keep it island!
author: Dee S.

description:
came on a night when they roasted the pig. i've had plenty of roasted whole pig at chinese restaurants, and so not surprisingly i was not thrilled by prubechu's roast pig that night. i guess i was expecting more of an island version wrapped in banana leaf or something, but what i found was something i could've gotten at any chinese restaurant. 

what i found delicious though was the rice and all the other sides they served along with the pig. im convinced i will be back for their fixed menu or al la carte, but probably not the roast pig. 

the service was quite friendly and the owner/host was very engageable.
author: Long C.

description: Where else could you find Guamanian food other than San Francisco! Very good service and very good and interesting food!
author: Kirk P.

description:
What a treat! Once you enter the unassuming storefront on Mission Street, get ready to be taken on a journey of deliciousness. It smells incredible as soon as you walk in (partially because, as I found out later, the ventilation in this space is extremely poor).

My friends and I went for the tasting menu - it came with a bread course, 5 savory courses, and a dessert for $65. The price is quite reasonable for the quality and quantity of food; however, if you are looking for an even better value, go for the a la carte options on the menu.

I would've loved to get a printout of the tasting menu; without it, I will try my best to describe what we had:

1) Bread - It had a soft texture and sweet flavor like Hawaiian bread, only even better.
2) Tostada thing with seafood ceviche - The slices of celery were incredibly refreshing
3) Spam fried rice with lightly fried soft boiled egg - OMG, this was so good. The egg had a somewhat runny yoke and the rice was incredibly tasty.
4) Chicken and something sausage concoction wrapped in a leaf - This was good but it didn't stand out as much as the other dishes.
5) Porridge like "stew" with wild mushrooms - Yes! Give me more
6) Halibut with fingerling potatoes - Eh, my least favorite dish. It was alright.
7) Coconut ice cream - So freaking good!

We shared a bottle of True Myth Cabernet, which was excellent tasting and easy on the wallet.

It's not easy to find Chamorro food and this meal made me want to go visit Guam.
author: Yi Z.

description:
Have you seen Ratatouille? You know that moment when Remy takes a bite of the cheese, then takes a bite of the strawberry, then shoves both in his mouth and fireworks appear? That's how I felt when I was at Prubechu. I was intrigued by how familiar Chamorro food is to the palate (heavy American influence), and was pleasantly surprised by the warm service and cozy design. Above all though, what I feel Prubechu does best is producing what Remy feels that moment he has both the strawberry and cheese in his mouth, FIREWORKS. Prubechu knows what ingredients work with what, and how to elevate flavors to the next level, all whilst doing it in an incredibly unique and new way! Absolutely loved it.

(If you have no idea what I'm mentioning above, see here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yyah49_Oz78)

Now let's dive into each dish. We did the tasting menu with a side order of flatbreads, which my boyfriend loved, paired with their special house butter:

-Bread & Butter: Can we just talk about how soft and moist the bread is? Piping hot straight from the oven. Great start to the meal.

-"Chicken Pot Pie" as I like to say: Creamy chicken with peas, crispy chicken skin, and pea sprouts. LOVED IT. Tasted like a lighter version of the inside of a chicken pot pie. The peas were very fresh and sweet and added such a lightness to the heavier chicken cream dish. The crispy chicken skin reminded me of the outside of a chicken pot pie, crispy and salty, love! 

-Spam & Eggs: PHENOMENAL. My favorite dish! Perfectly cooked soft boiled egg, crispy spam with a soy sauce like sauce drizzled overtop, paired with asparagus and avocado puree. WOW. This is where I really got that Remy feeling, those fireworks. The avocado puree added such creaminess yet freshness to the dish, emphasized by the asparagus. Egg was perfect and whatever sauce they used tied it all together. PERFECT.

-Beef Egg Roll: Again, phenomenal use of flavors. Fresh light tartness from the cucumer salad on top, creamy sweet spinach below, and spicy meaty filling in the egg roll. Exquisite!

-Porridge with Wild Mushrooms and Black Truffle Caviar (additional $10): incredibly flavorful again to no surprise! I found this dish a bit too heavy for me, and couldn't finish it all (which is when the bf hopped in). Lots of creaminess from the mushrooms and porridge and a nice hint of brininess with the caviar. Beautifully paired.

-Pork Belly: And I thought the meal was over until we were served this! Crispy pork belly with carrots and swiss chard. That pork belly was GOOD, super crispy, juicy, flavorful and paired with the two sauces, carrot, and swiss chard...again, FIREWORKS.

-Roasted Banana Ice Cream: I usually hate banana ice cream because I hate the fake banana taste, but since this was made from scratch from real bananas, it tasted real good! Loved the chocolate drizzle over top and they sprinkle some sea salt to really enhance the sweetness. Unfortunately mine had a bit too much salt but hey, can't go wrong with dessert!

All in all, I'll def be back! Looking forward to trying separate items on their menu like their fish imported straight from Guam. Impeccable food and service! Best kept secret in SF!
author: Cynthia H.

description: Small and romantic place with the benefit of serving food fare that you don't usually come across. We went for my husband's birthday. This restaurant serves Chamorro traditional food, so you may not recognize the things on the menu, but they translate to comfort foods with a tropical flare. I would highly recommend the potato soup, the short ribs, and the banana donuts. As a side note, their beer selection is excellent.
author: Taryn W.

description:
I was intrigued when I read "Guamanian" as I was scrolling through random restaurants on yelp, then I clicked it and looked at the photos and saw the SPAM which unfortunately is not on their menu. I'm not sure if it's something you have to ask for but we decided to stick to the menu instead. After having dinner here I then realized that I am not really a fan of this type of cuisine, although we did only order 3 things off of the menu so I can't really tell based off of what we had. 

We were waiting a little longer than usual for our food but I can understand because it was a Friday night and the place was full. Their staff was friendly and the service was good, they refilled our glasses with water every time we took a sip. 

The empanadas were my favorite out of the 3 items, it was served hot and fresh. The Tinaktak was alright, it kind of reminded me of beef stroganoff but with an asian twist because they used coconut milk to cook it. I didn't really enjoy the chicken ceviche wrap, but to be fair I don't like ceviche in general and this wasn't my choice I just had a taste of it.

I would still recommend this place though, if you want to try something different or maybe you're curious about what food from Guam tastes like then you should definitely try it out!!
author: Nicole D.

description: asbor/flavour: 9/10 - Servicio/Service: 9/10  Sabe como se ve/tastes how it looks: igual/same - Precio/price: $$$. The food here was absolutely amazing! I had never tried food from Guam and i thought it was great! Definitely try the Tinatak
author: Maria O.

description: Good food and great service.  However, I wouldn't recommend the tasting menu.  All of the food on the tasting menu is good, but it will not wow you for the price point.  I'd recommend picking a few things off of the menu and splitting them with friends!
author: Max G.

description:
Fantastic Chamorro food though not traditional.
 
Instead of the usual fiesta plates, this place provides a fine dining culinary experience by improvising on authentic recipes to take it to a whole another level. They experiment with traditional recipes, add a twist to it and make it their own. It works and thats all i care about.

Service is excellent. Crew is all Chamorro who grew up in Guam and they tell the story and tradition behind each dish. Even the chef stops by to check on you. I was there with my Chamorro friend and he quite liked the flavors as well.

We tried the Tasting Menu that comes with a 5 course meal and you are surprised with a 6th course. Tasting menu changes everyday based on chef's choice. So go with an open mind, you wont be disappointed. Empanadas were on point with complex flavors served with a coconut sauce.  House-made spam was just delicious. It was juicy with a lightly breaded crust served with greens and avocado sauce.

To finish off the dinner, we had their bunelos aga (banana donut). Yummilicious!

They cook all of their food on electric induction stoves which is pretty amazing.

I will go there for sure next time i'm in SF and highly recommend this place.
author: Sujeesha V.

description:
What a hidden gem. GEM, I tell you. 

We came for our 9th anniversary on a Wednesday night -- just half a block from the 24th street BART, but inside an oasis of calm clean lines and a quietly efficient open kitchen. 

The menu had a lot of fascinating items -- chicken ceviche? Coconut flatbread?! But we opted for the 6 course tasting menu, which had nothing from the alacarte menu and changes, apparently, very often. 

It started with mini rolls -- a sort of cross between Parker house rolls and Hawaiian sweet rolls, served with tuba butter. (Tuba, we are told, is coconut sap, which is made into wine). The rolls arrive tiny and hot, with big flakes of salt and black sesame on top. They are soft, moist and pillowy, but substantive. 

Next came an heirloom tomato salad, with bitter melon, anchovy salsa, and house made shrimp chips! The shrimp chips weren't as puffy as the kind you buy at the store, the ones that stick to your tongue when you put them in your mouth... you know what I'm talking about. But they did taste exactly like shrimp chips, and I was super impressed that they even thought of making them -- it's like trying to make your own pringles or something, seemingly impossible to achieve with human hands. The bitter melon is an acquired taste, one that I am only now starting to develop after a lifetime of being Chinese (American) but there are just a few pieces so it's a low key way to taste it without being overwhelmed. (It's hella good for you so it's worth trying to like it.)

The next dish brought another housemade version of junk food: spam! This was my favorite dish of the night -- a corn soup, enriched with coconut milk, redolent of  corn but accented by squares of pork shoulder that were dubbed spam. Much better than the canned variety, this version was smoky and salty, a perfect counterpoint to the sweet corn and crisp onions. 

But wait! I think this next dish was my fave. A bowl of rice porridge that was thick and creamy, the grains of rice blended to be indistinguishable yet retaining a slight bite of texture, tinted orange from achote, and unexpectedly exploding with umami. Topped with maitake mushrooms, a crispy fried soft boiled egg (runny yolk!), and that topped with black truffle tapioca (a $10 add on that made this dish unforgettable) this was somehow comfort food that you've never had before but wish you could eat every Sunday. 

I really was stuffed at this point but the waiter-who-is-also-an-owner brought out a dish of fried cod on a bed of baby bok choy with microgreens. He poured on an amazing broth made from the bones of the cod which was rich and layered with so much complexity. My husband deemed it his favorite of the night. The fish was a tad overfried but still was thoroughly enjoyable. At this point I had to take it to go, because I was unable to go on. It made a lovely snack the next day.

Of course I still had dessert stomach ... which our waiter-owner brought out with a candle to commemorate our anniversary. Very sweet. It was apigigi- cassava and coconut wrapped in banana leaves like a tamale, topped with strawberries. It sounds humble but it's one of those things you just don't want to stop eating until suddenly it's gone. 

The service was friendly, well paced, and attentive without hovering. We were one of just a couple of tables, which makes no sense: great food, flavor profiles that you can't get anywhere else, open kitchen, vegetable forward -- everything that's in demand right now. So I kind of want this place to blow up, because the one Gaumanian (Chamorro) restaurant in the city really should get the chance to thrive, but I don't want it to get so trendy it becomes impossible to get a reservation. Right now it's calm enough to bring your parents out have a good long chat with a long lost friend, and unusual enough to feel like an adventure. We will be back to try the regular menu or to beg for more porridge.
author: Jennifer H.

description:
Pricey but worth it!
I've never had Gaum food before but the pork rib was really good; sauce on the pork rib makes it melt in the mouth
author: Sammie B.

description:
Do NOT do the Tasting Course. It's an absolute SCAM. Seriously, WTF.

How do you force people to do the tasting course just because your over 4 guests? We were at 5 guests for a low key birthday dinner.

Anyways we hesitantly accepted to do the tasting course since their regular menu is bomb. But why not, give it a shot.... 

Thought it started decent with some delicious bread rolls then it went down hill from there. Basically the rest of the course was basically a squash soup, 1 sausage that was just ok, and 1 shrimp, and some sad porridge rice dish where the base was the earlier squash soup but turned into a thicker sauce. Oh and some bland coconut dessert that we left alone.

$65 for that garbage of a set up per person.

I don't mind paying x amount if the food is amazing. Food has no price if its good. This was a rip. Shit food courses that left you starving. We had to order their Fish at the end. Left there reeking of fried oil because dinner service took more than 3 hours. Unbelievable really. 

How can their regular menu be amazing, and their pre fix tasting the total opposite? Very unfortunate as I would of easily been a regular here. But the feeling of that night's experience and being ripped off will leave me bitter to never return.

To the chef/ owner. Stick to your regular menu and expand on having the dishes more sharing style. Drop your poor excuse of an attempt of a wannabe Michelin pretentious pre-fix coursing. Its Guamanian food for F sakes.
author: Charles L.

description: Had their tasting menu back in February. My mouth experienced a huge range of tastes here. Super cheap for a tasting menu 65$! Very interesting place and the feeling was very intimate.
author: Kimberly J.

description: Great food overall. I am giving four stars because after dining here 2 times I found a couple inconsistencies and was slightly disappointed after my second visit because I was raving about what I experienced the 1st time and brought someone to try the restaurant for their first time and when I ordered a couple same dishes it wasn't exactly the presentation as what I experienced. I really love the restaurant and it is very delicious food And I will definitely return again.  I just wanted to point out that for instance I ordered the Red Rice dish which has smoked meats and the first time I had it it was a mix of pork belly that was seared perfectly with sliced pork but also had a sample of ribs. The same ribs that we experienced as an appetizer before we had this as a main course. See my picture posted. Not sure if that was just something that was given to us special? but the second time I ordered it there were no ribs on this dish which is why I didn't order the ribs as an appetizer for my guest to try on their first experience eating here because I assumed they were going to be a couple on the red rice platter. Also the pork belly was not seared (or roasted more crisp?) the same and seemed very fatty nor had a nice crisp bite to it which with pork belly it's a hit or miss because then it can taste like a piece of fat you want to spit out. It was cooked excellent the first time. The red rice dish is served  broccolini which I love but first time there was also some micro greens garnish too? The salad we tried the second time was delicious with fresh beets and avocado, fresh vinaigrette. I appreciate the fact that the server presented the food and explained in detail what we were about to try which is a nice touch. Definitely love the Tinaktak - handmade noodles mushrooms, braised beef and sauce that has a nice hint of citrus served with green beans. The chicken ceviche is a winner - Kelaguen. Try it it's wonderful served with an aoli that has slight spicy kick and warm titiyas - coconut type a flat bread that you fill with the chicken and fresh coconut.  Overall I really enjoyed the food at this restaurant and it is worth visiting and to try a new experience in SF which truly sets this restaurant apart from the dozens of Japanese Mexican, Korean, Italian etc restaurants we have as many options to enjoy.  Prubechu is worth visiting if you've never had "Chamorro food" and curious about Guam style native cuisine.
author: Noey G.

description: Really good food and excellent customer service. Hole in the wall location and parking is a pain but well worth the effort. The restaurant is clean and well kept. This place must have been a bar prior as there is no built in stoves or oven. The chefs use several electric stoves on countertops. The pricing on their menu for the most part is fair however imo avoid red rice, fish entree and dessert. Reason being it's well over priced for their size. I just can't justify 3"x3" piece of fish, $28 bowl of rice not $10 sliver of coconut rice. ALL their food items taste great and they've said their tasting menu is one of a kind.
author: Cee B.

description:
Pleasant surprise. No familiarity with chamorro cuisine. Clean, sleek interior with some personality. Interesting beer list. We had the pickles - exceptional.  Red beans, octopus ceviche, and the coconut lemon beef noodles. Everything was well plated, cooked beautifully, and interesting. The pork belly had a fine level of smoke that balanced the acidity in the companion sauce. The pinot by the pinot by the glass was solid.

Dessert was a smoked tapioca base done on a banana leaf with creme anglaise and strawberries.

Unpretentious, thoughtful, interesting food in a chill spot. Highly recommended.
author: David S.

description: The empanada, chicken "ceviche", ribs, and banana fritters were amazing. May be my favorite place in SF. May take a trip to Guam now.
author: Kartik S.

description:
We love this place!  The food is always great and the staff is always warm and welcoming.  Good vibes!  If you ever have an opportunity to attend one of their events you won't regret it.  I'd recommend this place to anyone. 

Chamorro food is very accessible so give these guys a try sometime!
author: Ian C.

description:
For two, we ordered: the pickles, tinaktak and red rice. 

Loved each dish but I think my favorite was the tinaktak. The ingredients alone were simple enough...but together?! Oh my lanta. Ground beef, mushroom, peas and noodles, with a coconut sauce that was OUT OF THIS WORLD. First time I've ever experienced a dish like that. 

Finished the night off with the coconut candy ice cream...topped with black sesame and sea salt. 

Next time I come, I'll go with a larger group because I plan on ordering the exact same items - in addition to new plates. 

Thanks for a great experience, Prubechu!
author: Sarah F.

description: Great spot with interesting food! Had their special which was a halibut head in a wonderful marinade/sauce.  Shared the red rice,ribs and a couple of other dishes. The service was professional
author: Kathleen C.

description: Hella good food! Sad that it's closing due to rent increase. I'm hoping for a relocation near me and even if not I will drive the distance to eat with these folks again. Great people, great service, great chef work, authentic tasting Guamanian food and absolutely delicious!!
author: Unhappy C.

description:
I've never had tried food from Guam before so I can't speak as to authenticity but the food was tasty! We tried the coconut braised beef, which looked a lot like beef stroganoff. It had a nice coconut milk flavor to it but the portion of noodles was smaller than other plates so the sauce to noodle ratio was off. The red rice with pork belly was a pretty large portion of tasty, mostly tender pork chunks and red rice. We also got the black cod fish collar and tail. It was steamed in a banana leaf which my friends like but I think would have preferred those cuts grilled. The one thing we did not care for was the shrimp ceviche and bread. The term ceviche is a little misleading because the shrimp tasted over cooked. It may have tasted better if the bread was toasted or fried like a tortilla. Apparently this is one of their signature items and there were many raves on yelp so maybe it was an off day. 

This place is pretty small and they don't have a real kitchen so don't be surprised if it takes awhile to get your food. Luckily we weren't too hungry when we arrived but don't come with a group bigger than 4. The people working here are really friendly though so I hope they are able to expand the kitchen a bit. Prices are also pretty reasonable for the portions.
author: Lainy C.

description: Never had Guamanian food before so was interested to try this place. Super cute restaurant with extremely friendly staff. And of course the food was delicious. The caramelized potato soup was like a comfort food but elevated. The red rice is a must, i wanted to take a whole tub of that home with me. The ribs were fall off the bone yummy!  And if you like spice you have to try their homemade hot sauce, it's has a huge kick!  I would definitely go back again and again!
author: Gina T.

description: So good! My Mom was born and raised in Guam. We ended up spending the night in the city and had to come check this place out! So glad we did! Everything was amazing! My favorite was the coconut candy ice cream and the shrimp kelaguen with the coconut titiyas!! And the Chamorro ribs and empanadas!! We will definitely be back! Thank you!!
author: Andrea F.

description: Great food. Cozy atmosphere, and we were pleasantly surprised with a live band that was excellent!!
author: Sarah J.

description: This place was amazing. I was very impressed with the testing menu at such a good price of $65 The restaurant has a fun and relaxed vibe. The food was fantastic, great introduction to Guamanian food. It was new to me, loved the favor. Met Chef Shawn naputi and manager Shawn Camacho, they both are very friendly. Highly recommended
author: Katie E.

description: Another awesome meal at Prubechu and met Sean for the first time. Super hospitable and prix fixe rocked. Thanks guys.
author: Bob K.

description:
This place is such a treasure!!!! I tried the Pork Belly Empanada, the Chicken Ceviche & the Beef Tinaktak. Every dish was super delicious, clearly made w love and served by warm friendly staff who were attentive to all our needs even on a busy Saturday night. I loved that the Ceviche was different than what I know a Ceviche to be...very well marinated, cut into tiny pieces and mixed w finely grated coconut pieces which made the flavor so rich & heavenly. The Tinaktak was paired w peas & mushroom made with creamy coconut milk over pasta. Not overly rich like regular cream can make you feel. 

Finally the dessert we had was the coconut candy ice cream which tasted like salted caramel ice cream but so much better because it had coconut chunks inside and was served w black sesame & special sea salt that I won't try to pronounce. 

One of the best meals I've ever had!
author: Jessica H.

description: We celebrated Mothers Day diner early on Saturday. We both had the Chefs Tasting. It was a delicious 5 course meal. The fresh ingredients showed in the flavor of each dish. My girlfriend is from Guam and this was a nostalgia trip.
author: David F.

description: They made super extra moves to cater my dads funeral.  My dad is from Saipan and good quality and quantity is super important.  They came through with the best island bbq.  They came in early to make t happen and I appreciate them.  They helped me honor my dad properly the guest were super islander and they loved it!!
author: Angela B.

description: Love this place. Sweet and mellow. Every bite is an inspiration. My brother ordered the potato soup, I thought why? But it was amazing. Rich, complex, delicious. And big bowl for us to share. The wine list is short and every glass amazing. They pick the best. Every dish is delicious.
author: A F.

description:
'Bechu never had Guamanian before. The verdict? GUAM food is da BOMB food! I must return again for chaMORro'f the good stuff -- namely, ISLE be back to try out their Chef's Tasting Menu.

4   S T A R S

* NO RARER FARE IN THE BAY-AIR
Probechu's Michelin-recommended Guamanian/Chamorro cuisine consists of savory meats/seafood, coconut and tropical roots/vegetables, and some Filipino/Spanish influences. Their rare fare is well worth the bridge toll, probably worth a quarter-tank of gas, and possibly even worth the price of SF Mission parking.

* CHOMPING AT THE BITes
:::: Tinaktak, $19 -- BOOM-SHACKA-LACK! Pasta and ground beef baptized in a dee-luscious coconut sauce.
:::: Red Rice, $28 -- OINK PARADISE. Home-cooked lovin' stirred into the achuete-red fried rice, and featuring grilled bittermelon and pork belly. The pork, although quite dry, is superbly smoked in cherry wood and even more flavorful with the vinegar dressing added.
:::: Kelaguen Shrimp, $18 -- FOODYEAR BLIMP! Deelish shrimp ceviche with a sparkle of lime, topped with pleasantly yummy shredded coconut -- but I disliked the thick Titiyas flatbread underneath.
:::: Chamorro Empanada, $7 -- GO TELL YA MADA! 'Bechu she'd like it to!
:::: Kelaguen Chicken, $16 -- WASN'T KICKIN. Decent chicken flavor, but didn't dig the Titiyas flatbread.

* TRUE BEER-LIEVER
Great beer menu leans towards light to medium bodied brews. The following summery dranks paired well with the grub.
:::: Sofie by Goose Island -- YUMPLEXITY. Crisp Belgian complexity with a clean, citrusy ending.
:::: Grapefruit Sculpin IPA -- BUBBLY LUBBLY .. Balanced depth, hint of tart, finishing with mild hops.

* BOMBANIAN DESSERTS, $9.50 each
:::: Coconut Ice Cream -- A BUST-A-NUT-TWICE DREAM! Salty-sweet, tongue-curling foodgasm!
:::: Apigige -- MADE-AH-ME-GAY! A tender patty of tapioca and cassava is gently imbued with banana leaf essence, bathed in sweet coconut milk, and topped with strawberries.


1   M I N U S 

-(1/2) CHOKIN' ON BIG OL' TITIYAS
The Shrimp & Chicken Kelaguen were both served on dense, mouth-dryingly unpleasant flour tortillas called Titiyas -- which I left on the plate. If the Titiyas were half, or a third as thick then maybe they'd work, but as served they were a cotton-mouthed FAIL for the price.

-(1/2) NOT A FAN OF THE FANS
Prubechu's air is warm and stuffy because its converted, kitchen-less space doesn't feature a real ventilation system. Instead, whirring FLOOR FANS blast warm, marinated air through the dining area, and scent your clothes with smoke. I 'Bechu the stuffiness is even worse when the place is packed. If I'm paying San Francisco prices, then this distracting lack of proper ventilation shouldn't be part of the experience.
author: Art S.

description:
A great twist on traditional Chamorro food! I've wanted to try this place for a few years and finally made it out. My girlfriend and I were very happy with their ingredients and presentations. The tasting menu does not disappoint. They also have a great beer selection but even more fun was the Tuba (coconut palm wine). You can't get that every day.

If you want try a new style of cuisine I highly recommend this place. Chamorro food isn't widely represented and there's nothing quite like it. What this place does is elevate the style, it's a winner!
author: Jared P.

description: So delicious! We had the empanada and tinaktak noodles. Had no idea what to expect of food from Guam but were very pleasantly surprised. Noodles were so good we ordered a second serving.
author: Marilynne A.

description:
Prubechu had such a refreshing take on food that while you may or may not be familiar with they cook with a unique pairing of flavors - from coconut and lemon vinegrette and Asian with Island influences. It was absolutely delightful experience and so reasonably priced. Without drinks its was $35 a person and we ordered almost everything on the menu to share. The market salad was perfect, pickles included strawberries and bitter melon, empanada had this lovely heat/spice to it, the ceviche with flat bread are a must ( total comfort food/lots of flavor), red rice was pork cooked to melt in your mouth and my favorite the tinatak such a surprise - noodles in coconut sauce with a tart finish. 

They have great wine and beer selection and the service was excellent. Warm, attentive and relaxed. 

This place is focused on food and service, nothing hipster, nothing too cool. Just great overall experience.
author: Vivian C.

description: I went to this place a couple of years ago. My friend and I enjoyed it very much. This week, I took a group of 6 there. They insisted on a prix fixe menu during reservation, which was fine. They were also accommodating of a friend who is allergic to gluten. But, we were not impressed with the food. I don't think anyone in the group would visit again. The most disappointing part was the quantity of food served. A friend commented (I was also thinking the same) that she might need to go find a snack after as she was still hungry. We had 1 beer each, and with the 20% tip already included in the bill, it was $95 per person. I expect to be at the last fed well for that money. And the ambience was that of an $30 dinner per person restaurant. So, overall it gets 2 stars.
author: Arun R.

description:
I'd highly recommend Prubechu for their food, uniqueness, and the friendly, good vibes. If you haven't tried Chamoru food before, I'd describe the taste profile as similar to the sweetness of Thai, the variety of flavors of Indian, with some twists that could be tart or savory, perhaps with the delightful surprises of coconut or fish. Meat eaters AND vegetarians will not be disappointed. 

Prubechu is a dear place to me. Having grown up on Guam, my favorite cuisine is better than I remember at Prubechu. It feels like I get to have the grown up version with beautiful ingredients and a twist on the Chamoru classics. 

Also check out their special pig roast events!
author: Min Y.

description: Very unique and delicious flavors. Recommend the pre fixe if you're in the mood for something different.
author: Marcello B.

description: I went here for a birthday dinner and we had reservations at 9:00pm, but we weren't seated until 9:20pm. We ordered the six course tasting menu. The food was delicious and I highly recommend this place to anyone that has never tried Chamorro food. The best dish of the night was rice porridge topped with homemade spam, soft boiled egg, and caviar truffle. Kudos to all the staff for providing excellent customer service.
author: Billy L.

description:
First time having Guamanian food. It was delicious. Highlights were:

Food: we did one chef's tasting and 3 dishes off the menu. It was waaayyyy to much food. The chef's tasting has 5 savory dishes and 1 dessert course and the portions are fairly large. It's also hearty food so we were extremely full by the end of the meal. The potato soup, shrimp ceviche, egg dish, pork belly and short rib dishes were delicious. Not a huge fan of the sausage and the dessert. 

Drinks: their beer selection is great

Service: Sean was great. Knowledgeable, friendly and attentive. 

Highly recommended!
author: Laura D.

description: Staff is incredibly friendly.  Food is delicious and unique.  Reasonable prices.  We particularly enjoyed the Tinaktak and the potato soup.  We can't wait to come back and try the chef's special course.  Seems like the place can get crowded so reservations are recommended.  Luckily the staff squeezed us in at the community table.
author: Ken B.

description: As my first experience with Guamanian food and I was pleasantly surprised. Came here for a business meeting and were required to get the Chef's tasting. Normally I don't appreciate when a restaurant tells me what I will be eating instead of letting me pick my own meal, but considering I didn't know what most items were, and since everything they brought was delicious anyways, I didn't mind. The course was 5 dishes, which started with delicious sweet bread that comes with a vinegar coconut butter cream sauce. So good! Next was a shrimp donut, which was probably my favorite course. Perfectly fluffy, not crunchy and not overbearing in the shrimp flavor. Next was the Chicken sausage in a banana leaf. Yummy, but nothing amazing. Next was a Fried Egg in a soup type of porridge that had mushrooms and spam in it. I was hesitant to try this dish at first because I don't like mushrooms or spam, and before I knew it I cleared the entire dish. Next was a cod dish, which was okay, but I would of rather had more of that shrimp donut!
author: Run.It.Off V.

description:
So late on this review... Island time I guess. 
I was so excited when my sister found this place near my house. The food/experience was awesome! We now have a place to go to whenever we want authentic Chamorro food and I don't have to cook it. We started with the Empanada it tasted just like how grandma made it. For dinner we had Kelaguen Manok, Melaguen Uhang, & Tinaktak. The Red rice was BOMB!!! Ended the night with bunelos aga (banana donuts!) Everything we ate awe amazing. 
The atmosphere was chill & inviting. Service was outstanding we cant wait to go back and try the tasting menu! Si Yu'os Ma ase!!!
author: Lei S.

description: This place crushed it tonight. Came to Prubechu to celebrate my boyfriend's(he's from Guam btw) birthday. Best choice we could've made. Go with the tasting menu. Won't be disappointed. Tuba butter, corn soup with homemade spam, denanche mayo, chalaquiles, and coconut candy ice cream not only gave him the feels of home sweet Guam but blew me away at every nuanced n balanced but exciting bite!!! These guys are killing it here. To give y'all insight into these guys..They are pushing out amazing dishes n meals with no conventional fires of a traditional kitchen. Just go in and see. Thank you Prubechu for the welcoming island vibes n exceptional hospitality. We will be back;)
author: Kristi S.

description:
This review is only for the pre fix menu. We came tonight for my brothers bday, there was 5 of us. Had we known that if your party is 5+ people and you had to only order from the pre fix menu, then we wouldn't have gone. We decided to try the pre fix menu bc how bad could it be? I would say my whole family was very disappointed. ESP for my brother who has already been there before and tried the regular menu. Nothing was amazing about each dish. Hawaiian rolls? Soup (this was actually ok), the porridge??? This one sausage thing and one shrimp thing. We had to add the big fish on our order after not being satisfied. And yes! The fish is good! Sauce was amazing! But I realized that this place is really meant for small groups. Ideally 2-4. So please come here with 2-4 people. Def worth it. But not for larger parties. What was nice was that they took off some of the cheaper drinks we had off the bill bc they felt bad. So I appreciated that. Just make sure you have a lot to talk about with the people you come with, cause be prepared to wait in between each dish! 

To clarify again: regular menu- yes! 2-4 people- yes! Pre fix menu ? No! 5+ people? No!
author: Celine L.

description:
Food and service are amazing! Chefs are super attentive to dietary needs and restrictions. I was extremely excited to try this place out being my first Chamorro fusion experience. I ordered the tasting menu due to the fact that I couldn't make up my mind! Moments into my first bites, I felt at home! Each bite had me reminiscing and reminded me of my childhood. This place is a gem and such a treat! This restaurant is a MUST  if you're in San Francisco and searching for a unique dining experience. 

The only downfall is it's busy streets in the Mission so parking is literally a hit or miss. I recommend uber!
author: Alyssa S.

description: Excellent service, excellent food and drinks. It is awesome that you can make reservations as well. I tried the beef and the ceviche both were very good. The deserts are worth it as well. The prices are reasonable considering the quality of the food. Will definitely go back!
author: Sara-Fleur S.

description: Came here a week ago and still thinking about how delicious the corn coconut spam soup was! I had the tasting menu since I've never had Chamorro food and it did not disappoint! Both of my waiters were very friendly and I look forward to returning. I only wish that soup was on the actual menu, but I guess the exclusivity is what makes it extra special!
author: Erica C.

description: We were invited to this eatery by a friend.A very different kind of cousin.This is my first exposure to this Guam cousin.They use lots of vinegar,the pickle that we order consisted of sour hard boiled egg slices,bitter melon,daikon,strawberries,etc.But my 3 years old grandson likes their caramel I rd potato soup and red rice.The salad was delicious they use creamy sesame ginger dressing.If you are interested in food adventure,you may want to try it.
author: Heemay J.

description: Never have had Guam cuisine before and we were very impressed. Went in there without a clue what to order and just told them to bring us out whatever they thought we should try and it worked out wonderfully! The pork belly was crispy and delicious. Had no complaints with anything we were given!
author: Makenna C.

description: Amazing food and really great service. This is one of the few restaurants that have truly impressed me in San Francisco.
author: Ohnmar K.

description: Went here for my girlfriend's birthday which happens to be on Valentine's day. We were looking forwards to something a little different but it ended up being a little too out there for us. We didn't realise that the only option that day was the set / tasting menu (it would have been nice if they had mentioned it either of the two items they called to confirm the reservation) which was a lot of food. Staff and service were excellent and the ambience was nice (in that sort of modern American sense). We probably won't be back.
author: Sunil S.

description: I love this place! It makes my heart glad to see Chamorro food done up and given a fancy make over. I love good quality food and I love comfort food (which for me is the Chamorro food my Grandma made growing up), this is the best of both worlds. We have gone for dinner where we did the Chef's tasting menu plus a few extras and we have gone for their roast pig feast. Everything has always been outstanding from the food to the friendly staff. You feel very welcome coming to this place. Which reminds me, I need to go back.
author: Lelonnie E.

description: Read carefully, for 5 people you are forced into tasting menu@$90pp for 6 course tasting menu where bread is considered a course. The flavors are interesting but the hefty price tag doesnt commensurate the ingredients, the ambience, or the service or the fact that bread is considered a course. At $500 plus gratuity for 5 people with a beer each, its hard to give the stars. I appreciate the attempt to make something unique but it feels like a shakedown vs a tasting menu experience in great culinary delights:(. It feels like the restaurant is hemorrhaging money which I empathize with, but its hard to justify the price for what you recieve in return.
author: Nora B.

description:
Dinner review.

Too many dishes to list out. This place is amazing. Authentic Guam food that is delicious and presented well.

Five course tasting option is all off menu and is a great experience.

Friendly and welcoming service from Guam locals.

Overall, for Guam style dishes in the city this is undoubtedly "as good as it gets."
author: Mark O.

description:
This review is for the 6 course tasting menu, currently priced at $65.

While the tasting menu was mostly good, it was wayyy over priced. The best dishes (forgive my poor memory) were the egg in rice porridge and the tomato soup. One of the dishes was just a pickled radish (?) with a tiny strawberry, so it's tough to call this a "6 course tasting menu". The amount of food was way off - This was the first time I felt hungry post-tasting menu. The meat dishes (swordfish and pork belly) were decent, but nothing crazy.

Al's Place nearby has a similar priced menu, is michelin starred, and left me feeling extremely satisfied. Come here to order a la carte - Don't get the tasting menu.
author: Tim M.

description:
I first came here to meet friends for dinner, knowing nothing about Chamorro food.  We had the tasting menu then. When they served our first dish, I immediately got hooked. However, what I like most about this place, other than the food, is the hospitality and service. Staff is very helpful, as they explain the dishes they serve and tie the history behind each one.

Since that first time, I've come here 4 diffident times, bringing new set of friends each time. My favorite dish here is definitely the Tinaktak.

This place has definitely made a fan.  Kudos to both Shawns for putting a twist to their native, and bringing them here to SF.
author: John S.

description:
First off, I'm from Guam and grew up surrounded by people cooking Chamorro food, so I have a pretty good palate for Chamorro cuisine. Off the bat, I didn't have too high a standard for Prubechu and was expecting something akin to Jamaican Grill (if you're from Guam, you know the reference), something commercial, something quick, something splattered on your plate in large quantities with little thought. 

Don't expect a traditionalist approach to Chamorro food that you'd find from your nånan biha or at fiestas. And It's not a touristy restaurant that you'd find back on-island that presents "authentic" Chamorro food. Think refined culinary practices meet Chamorro cuisine. 

I ordered the Shrimp Kelaguen and Red Rice plate (pork belly, tinala) and apigigi' for dessert. Every element of my dish was carefully constructed. Everything from the finadeni (soy sauce based dipping) to the seasoned vegetables on my plate were given a lot of attention to the tee. The finadeni was a small example of fine culinary practice that I immediately noticed even before tasting a single item of my dish. The finadeni, the staple gold dipping sauce to everything Chamorro, was perfectly balanced and had onion chunks that were finely cubed and consistent - such attention to minute details like this is something easily overlooked even in the Marianas and was an indicator of the type of quality gastronomy I was about to experience. Their pork belly was well-rendered with a fantastic bark that had so much depth and nicely cut the richness of the pork belly. It had all you would expect from a traditional Chamorro pork belly but the treatment of such a simple dish was of such a high degree. I would never expect to find that pork belly at a fiesta table. The tinala, a dish that is often easily dried out and left hard and chewy, was moist and tender. You could taste the smoke penetrated flavors in the meat. Their shrimp kelaguen was refreshing and surprisingly incredibly fresh! For dessert was apigigi' but never had I eaten apigigi' adorned with anything except its banana leaf wrapping. My apigigi' was accompanied with strawberry compote slices and a cream mixture atop a traditional banana leaf. Definitely not your night market apigigi'. It was amazingly well complemented. It felt like an orchestra of flavors were playing in my mouth. Apigigi' had never been played with any other instrument till I had Prubechu's. In all, I didn't feel like there was anything on my plate that was simply thrown on as simple garnishing. Every element of my meal was well thought out, intentional and executed superbly. (They have seasonal tasting courses that I will definitely be back for!)

Prubechu treats Chamorro cuisine, as I have few times seen it treated in the restaurant, as a serious culinary cuisine. If you're looking for a replication of fiesta food, you'll find some of that, however, if you're looking to expand your idea of Chamorro cuisine, they push the envelope.
author: Leonardo O.

description:
Lovely low key but bustling spot on Mission.
Very interesting and tasty food.
Excellent service to round everything out.
I give 5 stars to places I would return to.
author: lisa s.

description: Wanted to get a decent meal after late meetings in the city. Found parking nearby and decided to give Prubechu a go. Food is Guam inspired with subtle non-regional American influences. Tried the chef's tasting menu... every bite was intriguing and delicious. I highly recommend this place if you're in the area!
author: Corey B.

description: We stumbled across Prubechu while walking down the street. Our host/waiter very friendly and he did a great job managing all the tables at the restaurant that night. If you're like me, and you're not a fan of coconut, don't despair! Although most of the options on the menu include coconut, the host was kind enough to explain which items could be prepared without coconut. I really appreciated that. Prubechu has a really comfortable and welcoming atmosphere/vibe. And now I can say I've eaten Guamanian food!
author: Norita M.

description: My boyfriend brought me here as a surprise for our anniversary last June (yes, I'm that late in writing this review), and it was *amazing*. I'd consider myself a bit of a foodie, and every now and then we splurge on a meal, but I rarely find myself going "WOW" after a dish, even at SF's best restaurants (e.g. State Bird, Frances). That said, I was super pleasantly surprised when numerous dishes we had that night had that "WOW" factor, including the soup and the coconut ice cream. Also loved that the service was so great, and that they let you order 1 person prie fixe and 1 person a la carte if you so choose. Thanks, Prubechu, for an amazing night out! Will definitely be back!
author: Diana C.

description:
Recently went to dinner here with a friend and was happily surprised at how good the food was and so was the service.  Never had food from Guam before but now I am a fan!  Food was so good.  

The owner and her husband were there and the wife actually served us.  Really lovely people and love to see people follow their passion.  Great place.
author: Eric S.

description:
Food: 5 stars
Service: 5 stars
Ambiance: 4 stars
Final: 5 stars

Food from Guam to a whole new level. I'm no expert in this cuisine, but if this is my first introduction, then I'm hooked. Fresh local ingredients, cooked with sophisticated techniques, and seasoned to perfection. 

We went for a holiday party. Lots of options for the meat eaters (of course), but they made special accommodations for the vegetarians and those with special dietary needs. And those dishes were not after thoughts, but well made and well executed dishes. 

Located on Mission in a relatively nondescript location, but when you walk in, you feel like you're in someone's living room. Service is impeccable, and makes you feel like family. 

Guam food, Guam hospitality, all in the heart of San Francisco. The trip will be worth it.
author: Quy T.

description: The food is SO fresh. Best ribs I've ever had in my life. Tracy and Shawn are friendly, kind hosts - we ordered what they recommended and I am so glad that we did. Please eat the coconut candy ice cream! I didn't know ice cream could have 4 flavors. My palette will never be the same after Prubechu has spoiled it with me heir delightfully sensational food!
author: Mike S.

description: This place was soooo amazing. What an array of flavor. I was very impressed with the tasting menu at such a good price of $65. I cannot remember what everything was called but it was one surprise after another. If you are open minded and love food then this is the spot. Way underpriced for the quality. I will be back as soon as I can. Keep up the good work.
author: Aj M.

description:
I really don't enjoy writing negative reviews, but I figure I owe it to other Yelp readers to share my experience at Prubechu last night, so that maybe we can slow down the hype around this restaurant. 

Things I LIKED about the restaurant: 
1). The wait staff was kind and friendly
2). Pretty much everything tasted good 

Things that could be much better: 
1). There is basically no ventilation in this restaurant, other than them having the front door open all night and having floor fans blasting. Because the kitchen is right next to the dining area (without a wall) the air is very thick, and I ended up coming home with my clothes smelling like fried fish. Not exactly the sort of clean, comfortable ambience that you'd want on a date. 

2). Their Tasting Menu for $65 is a rip off, in my opinion. They like to surprise you with what you'll be served, so it was an even bigger disappointment to see such mediocre courses served: 
First course -- three small bread rolls. This should be a free side, not part of the tasting menu. 
Second course -- corn soup with homemade spam -- excellent! 
Third course -- some sort of flat bread with some veggies on top. The size was small, and it tasted OK. But again, the main ingredient here is flour. 
Fourth course -- 2 or 3 small pieces of pork belly, and a few small potatoes. Is this was supposed to be the "wow" part of the meal, it certainly was underwhelming 
Fifth course -- coconut ice cream -- tasted good, but I'm not sure why I had to wait 30 minutes after the last course to get this. 
My understanding is that a tasting menu is supposed to be the highlights of what a restaurant has to offer. It was very unsatisfying -- and even more at this price. 

3). I ordered the fried fish head for $32. At the time, I thought I was getting a whole fried fish, head included. But instead, I got a bed of veggies, and a fried fish head. Yes, my wife and I were able to dig out about 4 forkfuls of meat, but this absolutely should not count as a main course. It might have made sense as a side, for $18. 

I told our server that I thought the fishhead was a ripoff. He apologized, and eventually gave my wife and me complimentary glasses of wine. This was very nice on his part, but did not really undo the fact that I think this restaurant represents the worst of the food scene in SF -- overpriced, overhyped new restaurants. We spent $180 for dinner (including a bottle of wine) whereas for that money we could have gone to nearly Lolinda and eaten great. Or more satisfying would have been the nearby Taqueria -- simple food, but good amounts of meat, great flavors, and non-crazy prices.
author: Jim M.

description: After walking by this restaurant a dozen times, I finally stopped by for dinner...and now I only wish I had come sooner.  The restaurant has a fun and relaxed vibe where the music creates an atmosphere but doesn't dominate your conversations.  The dishes I tried had expertly balanced flavors and textures while also staying true to authentic Guamanian cuisine.  I started off with the empanada.  Perfectly cooked so it was crunchy without any hint of oiliness.  It was balanced with a small salad that added freshness.  The flavors in the salad were so impressive that I'd order it as a stand-alone course.  I had the red rice as a main course.  It had a medley of smoked pork that was crispy and tender.  The amount of smoke in the meat was flavorful without overpowering the other flavors in the meat.  It came with a medley of grilled vegetables, pickles and a soy/vinegar sauce that perfectly offset the fat from the pork.  The side of flavorful red rice was the appropriate starch to complimented the pork.  I'll definitely be coming back soon and will be bringing friends.
author: Craig S.

description: What a surprise in the Mission. This would be only my second time having Chamorro food, but I have to say this is an elevated take on it. Everything came out fresh and delicious, my only gripe and the reason to bring it down a star would be for the pace of the prix fixe, don't get me wrong we both tend to eat really quickly, but there were times where we really felt like we were waiting for too long and in their defense they were getting busy so it's really not the end of the world. Other than that a really great arrangement of beers to choose from and friendly/informational service. I will say that I did leave full, but the dessert didn't quite feel fulfilling enough, it was almost more of an amuse bouche, but hey it was truly delicious and fun to eat. The flavors were literally all over the map, which was a great experience. I highly recommend this restaurant if you're in the mood for something a little off the beaten path. It truly was a culinary adventure and we appreciated it. Thank you for the special night, we'll be back to try a la carte items next time!
author: Guisela L.

description: This place is AMAZING! 6 course tasting is the way to go. Everything came out to perfection, completely blown away by the presentation and wide variety of tastes. I am infidelity coming back here, not only was the food great but the services was even better.
author: Adriana A.

description: Had a truly delicious, one of a kind tasting menu at Prubecho last night with my family. Everyone loved the food. Each dish was unique. From the fresh corn soup to the caviar and "fried-chicken" skin egg, we loved every bite. Aside from the incredible meal, the staff and ambiance are great. Highly recommend this place on date night or with big family like mine.
author: Lulu S.

description: The best part of living in San Francisco: FOOD. Have you ever had Guamanian food? Me neither. Do yourself a favor and EAT HERE. Like yesterday. Let me tell you: to DIE FOR. Guam style flatbread with tuba butter. Butternut squash soup with ginger, garlic, fried Brussels sprouts, persimmon, macadamia. Fried egg with black truffle caviar, white beans, avocado, homemade Spam. Homemade chicken sausage with coconut milk soaked spinach, fried chicken skin, boonie pepper paste. Guam style rice porridge with fried onion, black sesame, spinach. Pork tenderloin in a sweet beet paste with carrot, potatoes, island herbs and beet sprouts. And finally sugared coconut ice cream with sea salt and black sesame. Service: 10 stars, food: 1,000 stars. You can really tell the check enjoys cooking and enjoys sharing it with others.
author: Stephanie W.

description: Delicious. Welcoming. Great service. A true neighborhood gem. Save room for dessert though, you won't regret it!
author: Cal B.

description: We had a fantastic meal at Prubechu!  Loved absolutely everything.  The food, the wine, the service.  We had the soup (plenty for 2), the empanadas and the Tinaktak.  All the ingredients were so fresh and the flavors so unique.  I have a new appreciation for Guamanian food.  The restaurant is small and cozy as well. And the staff is beyond welcoming.  I have since come to realize that we were partly taken care of by Sean, the owner.  It was incredibly affordable as well.  We plan on making this a regular stop.
author: Kari G.

description: Been meaning to finally get out here and try one of the only few Chamorro food restaurants in the Bay. Friends of mine had the red rice plate and that was a hit. I can tell a lot of care went into the dishes we ate. The finadeni is done nicely, I like mine with a bit more heat though. I went with the tasting menu and it exceeded my expectations. It was a lot of food so 2 people could share this easily. All the dishes were very different in flavor and texture and the last main dish of the chicken sausage with herbs was absolutely fantastic! We had great service from Shaun and I purposely did not get the kelaguin and other classic dishes so I can go back and try it soon one day!!! Do yourself a favor and give this spot a try and you will be satisfied!!!
author: Leo C.

description:
Prubechu is a food experience gold mine.  They serve Chamorro food with a twist.  You will be amazed by all the wonderful flavors that are incorporated into each dish.  The base of the dish is traditional but the chef has added an element or two to evelate it to something that is both  surprising and game changing.  We had the tasting menu and every course was delicious.  We had six coruses and were delighted wirh each one.  The coconut candy ice cream for desert was mind blowing - creamy and coconutty with crunchy surprises mixed in. Yum!  If you have not had a taste of Guam you must visit Prubechu.  It's definitely not Nana's cooking but let me tell you she taught her Grandsons well. 

Biba Prubechu!
author: Laura E.

description: Love this place. Haven't ever tried the tasting menu, but their main menu is really reliable and delicious. Personally, I think the soup that they call caramelized onion soup has achieved soup perfection. The fish has always been fresh and wonderfully seasoned and delicious.
author: Janet S.

description:
We heard this place was fantastic....we are "foodies" (gasp) that horrible class of folk who proclaim to LOVE great food....and will scale small mountains to try "great" food.  We are also originally from Guam, the lovely, gorgeous Island that the food from Prubechu gets its kick start and its impetus. 
The menu is a nice combination of culinary finesse and island style meets sang-froid. Very cool.
If you want delightful, satisfying flavor combinations at every turn, go here. 
Don't let the menu fool you. You don't need to order the tasting menu to experience their wonderful flavors. You can experiment with individual items off the menu.

Great customer service, lounge like surroundings.. Very intimate and comfy. 

We will be back multiple times.
author: Kelley M.

description: I've been wanting to try this place for a while now. My cousin and I took our moms here for their birthdays. I wasn't sure if I'd like a twist on Chamorro food given it is amazing as is but the food here was better than I could have ever imagined! I had a little bit of everything. My cousin had their tasting menu which I sampled from...delicious. Every. Single. Dish. I had one of my favorite dishes ever, Tinaktak, and it did not disappoint. I was also looking forward to ordering their empanada, which until now I haven't find anybody who made it as good my grandma! Also, the corn soup and chicken keleguin was booomb!
author: Katrina F.

description:
While visiting the Bay Area, I've eaten at my share of restaurants, most of which met my expectations. 
  However, I was amazed to see the staff of the Prebechu establishment can not only give exceptional service, but can do so with a small amount of employees. As someone who works as a server himself, I can assure you that this is no easy task.
  The presentation of each dish was complemented with a simple yet enticing summary from the server. We were well taken care of throughout our dining experience.
  As for the cuisine? It was obvious each dish was beautifully and skillfully prepared. I was thoroughly pleased to encounter dishes that incorporate flavors from the pacific, in the city by the bay . Prebechu restaurant will always have a customer whenever I am visiting San Francisco .
author: Kenneth P.

description: Traci and Shawn were so attentive to all their customers. The food was delicious and so was the wine. The restaurant was able to make a special menu for them as we all tried the tasting menu.
author: Samuel K.

description:
I applaud the novelty and uniqueness of opening a Guam cuisine restaurant in San Francisco. I definitely tried a lot of new tastes here and had a pleasant experience but just don't think it's likely I'll return.

The set menu was $65/person for 5 course which wasn't a good deal. Portions were hefty for a tasting menu and I definitely left full, but it didn't have the elegance of a meal of that price.
