They didn't change out the utensils between courses so you often had some tastes mixing together. They did clear out and replace dishes at nice intervals and the staff was very friendly.

The food itself was a progression starting with a nice flat bread starter which wasn't part of the 5-courses and ended with a desert that also didn't count (so they do try to exceed expectations). So you are getting a 7 course meal in some ways. There was some interesting flavors ranging from the home made spam to the short rib in broth. Overall though there wasn't anything that I felt I absolutely had to have more of. There is no overlap of the tasting menu with the regular menu unfortunately.

If the menu was at the previous prices, I'd think it was a steal and be more forgiving. At these prices, I expect a lot more (even if it was less courses). Trestle in Financial District offers less courses (3 total) but for $35 with a more impressive atmosphere/setting. This place felt like a neighborhood Mission joint but trying to charge a lot for some nicely plated Guam food but without any killer dish or refined service.

Overall, I don't regret trying it, if only to see what Guam food is like and I can see the potential. I think they just overshot the mark on price and the expectations it set.
author: Victor W.

description:
2 STARS for food/value, 4 STARS for service.

If you look closely at the review of Prubechu, most Yelpers will agree on each dish being pretty disappointing. While $40 for a 5-course sounds like great value, esp given their predecesors (Roxy, Mr. Pollo) had done something similar you would think they wouldn't fall too far from the tree. Everything tasted and felt cheap, but at least now I can say I've had Guam food?

My only hesitation in writing this review is that the owners/managers were so amazing, and the wine was good and so reasonably priced! Well onto the reviews of each item we ordered:

* Complimentary Somerset Oyster (5 STARS): Delicious dressing, flavorful and fresh oyster. What an amazing way to start the meal unfortunately it was mostly downhill from here.

* Ahi Tuna Sashimi w/Egg (2 STARS): The tuna was shockingly low grade tasting, and I could probably make a better seasoned egg. A nice attempt at an upscale dish but not executed well and ingredients sub-par.

* Ceviche Style Chicken (1.5 STARS): An interesting dish which may originate from Guam? Not something I've ever had. The chicken is shredded and cooked ceviche style (with citrus juice). However, the end result is a dry tuna-like shredded chicken taco.

* Shrimp dish (1 STAR): I forget what this was called exactly but it comes in a small ceramic dish baked in a thick yellow sauce. I couldn't help but think how much it reminded me of United Airlines food on international flights.

* Rice, Pork, Potato Soup (3 STARS): This is good but tastes like the soup my mom makes when there is leftover rice which she rehydrates with extra pork soup.

* Porridge (5 STARS): I don't know exactly what was in this porridge, and I never though porridge could be this amazing, but it was really flavorful, savory, and delicious. I had to resist licking my bowl clean.

* Coconut Ice Cream with Candied Nuts (4.5 STARS): This was so delicious, especially with the candied nuts - I could eat it all day and would buy it to take home if I could! It was an amazing way to end the meal.

There were low lights and highlights, mostly low lights. A unique Guam meal, but the value wasn't there for me. Sorry guys!
author: Jess C.

description:
It's so hard to find this place (please put something more than the small printout with your restaurant's name up front!), but so worth it once you do!

The food's pretty good - 3.5 stars overall, all very interesting. But the service just blew me away. Our server was really friendly, seemed to be there whenever we needed him, & didn't charge us for two of our four beers (we tipped generously in response). They're very accommodating: any one person can get the 5-Course Tasting Menu (none of that everyone-at-the-table-must-order nonsense), which has TWO additional FREE courses. Our last course, the free one, normally comes with one scoop of ice cream but they gave us three (one for each of us!) so we could share it. Every dish that came out came with some unique backstory or ingredient & the chef who brought them out was very knowledgeable (though a different, much less articulate chef brought out one course & we could barely hear what he was saying. He seemed nervous & stumbled through his words quite a bit). 

Small complaint: it was a chilly SF summer night & despite sitting in the very back, I was really cold. I asked our server if he could close the door & he promised that he would in a couple minutes (they don't have a vent & need to air the kitchen out through the front door), but never ended up doing it. 

MUST-HAVES: Tinaktak (a la carte), the tasting menu (wish for the Chalakilis & Coconut Ice Cream).

A LA CARTE: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ
* Pickles (seasonal vegetables. $5) - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#5QMErbIJIYD06avwvhZeBA
My friend ordered this. I'm not a huge fan of pickles & didn't love this. This was the only dish that went unfinished at our table.

* Tinaktak (coconut braised beef, hand made pasta. $16) - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#mEUfPFG7OF4tLjpdOukdDQ
Fantastic. The pasta is very fresh & soft, the meat mixed into a thick creamy (but not too heavy!) sauce.

* Red Rice (achiote, brocollini, pork belly, tininu katne, fina'denne'. $18) - 3 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#YiG5x-QSJdoV-43fAv3zsQ
The rice has a slightly sticky texture & with its seasoning is good enough to on its own. However, we were disappointed with the meat: it was hard & dry. The "pork belly" was a few small, thin pieces of bacon that had zero texture & very little flavor.

5-COURSE TASTING (with free 1st & last courses)
* Oyster - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#lW6mhPGjFVdSGCr8M0LsfA
I forgot what topped this oyster (which was very fresh), but it was very exotic, unique, & delicious.

* Asparagus, salmon, fried nori - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#hDswws_Pt7IwN84TobTjhQ
Salmon never really impresses me but it actually did here! Very, very soft tender meat, both the rare part & the seared edges. The crunchy nori was absolutely fantastic.

* Shrimp, white corn patty - 3.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#kGD65eQR57LZasbXZHzcdw
cross-section: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#sut3l9j-ASIEfb7a9v9bYw
Nice but not an overly impressive dish. The patty is soft & the crunch from the white corn & the shrimp inside is nice.

* Escabeche - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#55V43ZLjIjUa6i177TUq5Q
A very interesting dish, & one with a story (Spanish-influenced & found in its own version everywhere the Spanish have conquered). Pickled items just aren't my thing, but the fried fish was really great, intense with flavor, & actually paired well with the pickled veggies!

* Chalakilis - 4.5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#iAR7Ri_6k0OeD-F0Pe21_g
We were amazed that this was only the 4th course! We were already getting stuffed. This had a nice thick grainy texture, though was a little lacking in flavor.

* Fish in coconut milk soup - 4 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#F2uP5wqRgVOQE3tkP4yhiQ
Loved the vermicelli noodle pieces, & the charred veggies were amazing. The soup was a bit watery to me, & the single piece of fish seemed out of place though its charred skin was nice. Watch out for bones!

* Coconut ice cream - 5 stars
pic: http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/prubechu-san-francisco?select=nE3dhWC14EmjZ6sb6DjgLQ#o5KboxIAyMQlhh6AfIgfoQ
Loved this! The most authentic coconut ice cream I've had, with tons of real coconut chunks. The cassava cake on the bottom was soft, thick, & chewy, & it paired incredibly well with the ice cream.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
4.5 STARS

First times tend to be awkward and frankly not very good. 

Think about your first kiss...the first time you boinked.... 

Are you getting a mental picture yet?

Ummm yah, I think the only memorable moment was being able to brag to your friends about how "awesome" it was to pop your cherry. More like awesomely awkward and disappointing especially if the dude's headgear cuts your lip but hey, no one has to know that. Shhhh...

Last night was the first time I tried Guam cuisine and it was anything but awkward or disappointing. Grand opening on Tuesday, Prubechu took over old Roxy's location. The executive chef previously worked with Chef Manny at Mr. Pollo and the GM previously worked at The Palace so it was no surprise to see a similar concept. Balling on a budget as I would call it. For just $40, you get a five course tasting menu plus two amuse bouches and a dessert which is a fantastic deal. There's also an a la carte menu available. Beer & wine only. CC's accepted. 

Prubechu is SF's first Guam restaurant so expect to see Spanish and Filipino influenced cuisine with a refined Californian twist. The chef shops daily for his ingredients so the menu may change on a daily basis depending on what's seasonally available. 

FIVE COURSE TASTING MENU - $40: http://bit.ly/1eXPm1d
*Amuse bouche: Oyster w/ coconut vinegar & kiwi: http://bit.ly/1lCMG1G
(1) 9 Minute Egg w/ avocado & caramelized soy: http://bit.ly/LBD1Ys
(2) Chicken Keleguan w/ coconut, scallion & titiyas & amuse bouche of pickled veggies: http://bit.ly/1btHZh6
(3) Shrimp Patty w/ corn & peppers: http://bit.ly/1iwq9i2
(4) Chalakilis w/ porridge, smoked pork belly,  achiote & quail egg: http://bit.ly/1g5Nsxm
(5) Kadu w/ short ribs, rice, peas, potato, mung bean sprouts: http://bit.ly/1fVXTEW
*Complimentary Housemade Coconut & Tahitian Vanilla Ice Cream: http://bit.ly/1iwqKjy

A freshly shucked oyster with a tropical twist nicely started our dinner. For the first course, I would have preferred a more runny egg but the creamy avocado and the savory pungent caramelized soy added another dimension that more than made up for it. Like a flatbread, the Chicken Keleguan was very satisfying especially with the kewpie and chili peppers for a creamy, fiery bite. The shrimp patty was presented as a "soufflé" but the texture was more like scrambled eggs. This was my least favorite of the tasting menu. 

Moving on to the more stick to your ribs courses, the Chalakilis was like a rendition of pork and grits. Slightly caramelized around the edges, the tender pork belly had a nice smokiness to it and was heightened when dipped into the runny quail egg. My favorite dish of the night was the Kadu. Comfort in a bowl, the chunk of English cut short rib was incredibly tender and totally hit a soft spot with the slightly sticky rice. 

The tasting menu ended with a complimentary dessert of Housemade Coconut & Tahitian Vanilla Ice Cream that was enjoyably rich and not too sweet. Loved the sprinkling of pie crust (?) for that textural contrast. 

Service was professional, knowledgeable, and attentive. Since Guam cuisine is new to many people, the staff was more than happy to explain it to us. Food service was timely. Expect to spend about 2 hours for the tasting menu. 

On the intimate side, Prubechu makes for a great date place. There's just six 2-tops, two 4-tops, one 6-top, and several counter seats overlooking the open kitchen  so do make reservations as I expect this place to get busy once the word gets out about this place. 

Overall, Prubechu's food is a solid 4 stars (there's always room for improvement right?) while service was 5 stars. 4.5 stars and rounding up for having the balls to open a restaurant with a cuisine that's unbeknownst to most. Especially to someone who thought Guam cuisine was Filipino cuisine. And, I'm part Filipina... =X
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
CHAMORROS KNOW HOW TO FEED PEOPLE!!!
(5 stars)

This is the first Guam/Chamorro restaurant in SF. Serving authentic home-cooked meals and elevate it to another level of art with elegance and extraordinary taste to give your palette an experience. 

- FOOD, so delicious and very filling (see my pictures)
- PRICES, fair
- SERVICE, the best, very professional
- AMBIANCE, simple - i like it

Thank you Chef Shaun and other Shaun for keeping me company and educating me on the art of Chamorro cooking. I have alot of Chamorro friends in WA and these two guys are now my first in SF. They just opened so their menu is limited for the moment. They have a 5 tasting course ($40 - and well worth it, those portions were mini meals) OR you can do an Ala Carte with two dishes. I chose the 5 tasting course to be able to consume multiple dishes in one sitting. Also, I was given other dishes to sample that were not on that tasting menu. 

ISLANDER GENEROSITY.

Tasting #1: MIYAGI w/ VINEGAR, COCONUT, AND KIWI DRESSING - I love fresh shucked oysters on its own with very minimal dressing because dressings usually mask the flavor of a raw oyster. The vinegar, coconut, and kiwi was a perfect light combination to compliment the miyagi oyster. the flavors were subtle. Light hints of coconut and kiwi were a hit for this dish. Also, I learned that the vinegar comes from the coconut tree. Very interesting information.

Tasting #2: EGG w/ AVOCADO AND CARAMELIZED SOY - this was not your typical boiled egg. The egg was soft boiled and very delicate. It was split in half and sitting on a fluff of creamy avocado puree, divided by the caramelized soy and drizzled with chickweed (the green stuff), and sprinkled lightly with Iranajan salt (that's a village in Guam - some lady takes the water from where the ocean and the river meet and goes through a process of fermentation to get the salt). Again, very interesting information. For me this dish had a play between salty and sweet, my palette loves salty and sweet combinations so I really enjoyed this dish. 

Tasting #3: CHICKEN KELEGUAN - served on flat bread made from coconut milk instead of water and topped with fennel sprouts. The flatbread was had a nice soft crunch on the edges and it is a little more dense then other flatbreads but it has a different flavor as it was made with coconut milk. the chicken keleguan was really good and and made with quality. It was topped with fennel sprouts which gave it color and some herbal flavor. TITIYAS!

Tasting #4: PICKLED VEGGIES - pickled cauliflower, pickled green daikon, pickled regular daikon, and pickled watermelon red radish. Everything pickled. My favorite was the pickled watermelon red radish.

Tasting #5: SHRIMP PATTY - shrimp patty and shaved Jerusalem artichokes & cucumbers. Usually shrimp patties are fried, their presentation was more of a souffle style. I'm use to the heavy shrimp patties and more oily but this one wasn't like that and had a "healthier" approach to it. The jerusalem artichokes and cucumbers were a nice palette refresher when eating something like a shrimp patty.

Tasting #6: CHALAKILIS - it's Guam's version of rice porridge. Served with rice, pork belly and braised smoked meat with tiny quail egg and flavors of tumeric. THIS WAS ONE OF MY FAVORITE DISHES OF THE EVENING. I love Chalakilis and this was SO BOMB. Very filling, it literally was a mini meal on its own. The porriadge was this deep tan color and it had an incredible flavor, the pork belly and smoked meat just put everything together. The boiled quail egg wasn't overly cooked, when I popped the quail egg in my mouth the yolk squirted out. YUM.

Tasting #7: KADU - shortrib, rice, peas, potato, mung bean sprouts, savory/rich soup base, and a dabble of finadene on top. This reminds me very much of a Filipno soup dish but a different twist to it. The shortrib was perfectly prepared and the soup base was very savory and rich, I can just eat the soup and rice by itself and be happy. THIS WAS MY OTHER FAVORITE DISH OF THE EVENING. I was so full after Tasting #6, I took a few bites of Tasting #7 and pack the rest up. 

Tasting #8: ICECREAM - dessert, "manha" (young coconut), Tahitian vanilla, cookie crumbles, and sweet pansies (flowers). HOUSEMADE. The icecream was the perfect way to end a very savory #7 course tasting meal. I love icecream so I know when to judge icecream. The young coconut flavor could be tasted and the after-taste of Tahitian vanilla. The cookie crumbles provided texture and enjoyed it. Who would have ever thought of eating flowers with your icecream, THEY DID. 

I left slightly bent over and can barely walk. THAT'S HOW GOOD THIS PLACE IS.

Will I be back? YOU DON'T HAVE TO ASK ME TWICE.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review...
author: Jane A.

description: Unexpected delicious place. We took the Prix fixe menu and it was fantastic. Run by 4 amazing persons from Guam.
author: Pierre F.

description:
This is my current favorite restaurant, which is great since I live blocks away. I had never heard / had food from Guam before, even though I've flown through their airport a few times criss-crossing the pacific on the way to other islands. Even if I had, I'm not sure it would have held up--these folks are wizards in the kitchen!

They definitely know their audience--young, more affluent, hip, and on the hunt for interesting, fun food. The range of flavors is great, their tasting menu is generous and inexpensive (compared to places of similar caliber of food), and the folks working there are passionate about what they're doing.

They've got a great selection of funky sour beers, which pair wonderfully with their foods, and the waitstaff have never led me astray.

I'll definitely be coming back on the reg.
author: Josh H.

description:
A nice addition to the Mission and the Bay Area. I think it is the only Guamanian restaurant.  Due to this and my heritage to Hawaii, I was excited to try the Chamorroan food.  My friends and I decided on the $40 5 course tasting menu.

The course began with a amuse buche of an oyster with a citrus seasoning from Guam. I couldn't taste the citrus, only the oyster.  

The first course was a boiled egg with caviar. It was a little salty, but not bad. 

The second course was the chicken kelegun which was a shredded chicken, spices, and served on a flat bread. This reminded me of chicken salad and not to my liking for texture and taste.

The third course was supposed to be the shrimp omelet, but they ran out of it.  They were saving it for the chefs friends table whom we saw were served the dish, though they were seated after us by 20 minutes. We were served with a a shoyu picked eggplant, vegetable variety dish. I thought it was tasty, as shoyu and picked is always good. But it was a slight heavy on the shoyu.

The fourth course was the one that I enjoyed the most. It was a braised pork stew served with rice porridge.  The dish was smoky and the taste was prominent throughout the entire dish and bite.  A really good dish.

The fifth course was a clear broth soup with beef (I think) and rice.  This course irritated me the most. Only because the execution of the dish was off. We had to ask for spoons, rather than the staff set spoons down before serving the dish. They realized the mistake, but still this small execution bothered me. The dish wasn't bad, as the flavors were nice due to the additional sauce you can pour it. It was a shoyu pickled base sauce which really brought out the flavors of the beef and the broth.  

Dessert was coconut ice cream.  Sweet and with a good flavor of coconut, it ended the course well. 

I think if they continue to improve on the execution of the service this restaurant will do well.   It is still young, so if people could help support it as the lone Guamanian restaurant in the city they will improve in both food and service.
author: Marck N.

description:
Go here!

This is an overlooked gem serving delicious Guamanian cuisine. We ordered almost one of everything on the menu between our group of four and liked every dish. We finished with a round of desserts that left us wishing we had room for more. Combined with the refreshing tuba (coconut wine) and passion fruit beer cocktail and extensive beer and wine list, Prubechu is a good value for the high level of execution and quality ingredients. It's a great mix of Asian and international influences with a distinctive flavor that I haven't found anywhere else. Definitely going on my regular rotation.
author: Navi O.

description: Flawless meal. Did the the 6-course tasting and it was perfection. Coupled with the wonderful service-you couldn't ask for a better date night spot. Definitely plan on a repeat performance.
author: Ajita M.

description:
One star is not even worth for this restaurant. Well, maybe one star for decent service.
We had shrimp ceviche, potato soup and Spring vegetables. 

Potato soup ($9) was quite blend. 

Shrimp ceviche ($18) was just okay. It had pita type of breads on the bottom, which was not fresh at all. It tasted like the breads were sitting in the freezer for long time. 

Spring veges($17) comes with seasonal veges and coconut sauce. It was a best dish that we had in the restaurant but It's hard to mess up with coconut sauce. It was nothing special for the price. 

I wouldn't come here again :(
author: Erin P.

description:
Prubechu is off the hook!!

Been wanting to come here since they converted from being Roxy's, and finally decided to take my work team for dinner here.

Inside still looks like the old Roxy's space, small, simple and no major kitchen - all induction burners and open kitchen style.  But this doesn't affect anything, the food is absolutely fantastic!

The duo of front of house Shawn and chef Shawn hold it down.  The whole squad is from Guam, and they are representing proper.

Had the 5 course tasting menu - but with the starter and dessert it was 7 awesome courses.  

Started with a flatbread with some insanely tasty coconut butter, and a daikon pickle thing.  Then was a fried, soft boiled egg with various delicious add ons, followed by a chicken sausage type thing in a banana leaf with an dope but scorching hot sauce. Then a fried red rice type of dish with a quail egg and house made spam (!!!!!).  Followed by a porridge dish with pork and finally a short rib dish.  Finished with a coconut candy ice cream.  

The food was amazing, and broke any cliches about Guamanian bbq and other simple island cliches.  It was homey flavors plated in a super refined elegant way, served in a casual, cozy environment.  Service was friendly and white table cloth level care, without being fussy.

Can't recommend this place enough.  It might be the best $55 tasting menu in SF!
author: Arthur Y.

description: This was one of the BEST meals I've had in a very long time. I had the shrimp kelaguin which was packed with amazing flavors & served on top of a homemade titiya. The red rice is just like grandma use to make. The banana donuts with coconut creme are the perfect finish. The service is top notch real Chamorro hospitality. Can't wait to come back.
author: Rene P.

description: First time trying Guam food. I quite liked it... Tasted like Hawaiian food but less sweet and less ghetto lol
author: Betty T.

description:
Delicious food and service. My favorite was the pork dish (cant remember the name) with pickled veggies. It tasted like jerky, so delicious. The red rice is also a must. 

Shoutout the the live entertainment! The guitar player is super talented. 

Will definitely return.
author: Susana M.

description: We have been in here twice now, did the tasting both times. The food is excellent, and the service is very friendly. This is a great spot.
author: Andrew B.

description: I came into this establishment last night after walking around mission street looking for something interesting to cure my hunger. My friend and I stumbled into this small yet intimate Guam restaurant. We had never tried Guam food, so we thought... Why not?! Let's give it a try. Our expectations were beyond exceeded. We ordered just about everything on the menu including the to die for red wine and banana bunuelo desert! Every plate was brought to us in a course style, which we enjoyed so much! Our waiter was extremely friendly and took the time to describe every dish to us. You could definitely sense his Iove for the food. I'm so glad we discovered this place. We will definitely be coming back the next time we are in SF.
author: Miranda R.

description:
I took my mother to eat here because this is one of the few restaurants in California that we know of that serves island inspired food specific to the Marianas. We were the first ones in the restaurant and arrived almost when it opened. When we left a 6 man party was being sat. Who were the only customers our whole visit.

Food:

Pros: Taste, presentation, serving size, and the overall rarity of the menu selection.

From when my party ordered, to when the food arrived was about average among restaurants.

Cons: Price for food is a little high, but I believe since this is the only restaurant in the city with this specific menu than its almost understood.

Customer Service:

Pros: Workers are all friendly, Greeting as soon as you walk in the door, constant attention to the table, and genuine connections instead of generic responses. The man who waited my table somewhat remembered me coming in from before, and the last time I was here was over 8months ago!

Cons: None that I can think of.

Atmosphere: 

Pros: Real relaxing, soft to upbeat island music, smell of the food being cooked really made it feel like you're waiting in the comfort of your home. 

Island themed decorations, informational books on the island, and home style in use wear (Lemon powder can) to deliver receipt.

Cons: If you're not used to an island style home, you might not understand the overall feel of the restaurant. If you choose to dine here, remember that to islanders, we try to treat everyone like family, and give you all the best welcome to our home as possible.

Other notes:
I suggest the Tinaktak for a good sized meal, or the red rice if you're a little more hungry. I tried all of the desserts and my favorite is the coconut candy Ice cream with Inarajan sea salt. I personally hate coconut in most of its forms but the combination of ingredients helped me find a new love for it. If you're looking to try something new to drink, inquire about the sweet tuba, it's really good. All in all great job guys! Keep up the good work.
author: Brandon I.

description:
Great service, nice waiters, but the worst food i have ever had. We got the tasting menu and it was so bad we actually left after only half of it , though we were still charged (and paid) the full bill.
If you like spam and eggs, this is the place for you. Or, you could save 100 bucks and buy spam and eggs and safeway and make it at home

I want to stress the wait staff was nice and cool but the food was horrific. I am not sure the protocol for ordering tasting menu and then eating 40% of it and leaving before it all comes out, but we were charged for it all. 
Very very very disappointing.
author: ryan s.

description: We absolutely loved our first Guam food experience of SF. We recently moved close by and are so happy we did. The food choices in the Mission are amazing. The service was warm, friendly, and we enjoyed the explanations of the food. We had the flatbread with butter and added hot sauce for the meal, potato soup, chicken and shrimp ceviche (Kelaguen), whole parrot fish with rice added, and the dessert was called Apigige. One of the waiters suggested the dessert as she used to have her mom freeze dry it in Guam and she would bring it back. We were sold! It was that delicious. Try a new culture, you might love it! ;)
author: Kelsey S.

description: This place is 10 out of 10! Incredible taste.  Every dish cooked to perfection.  If you come here there is no way you leave disappointed.  Chefs special is the way to go. My 2017 dinner of the year!!
author: Bob S.

description: Went last night for the six-dish tasting menu. Super unique and tasty food (and they made modifications based on food preferences at the table), exceptional and warm service, and nice environment. Will definitely return.
author: Inna T.

description: Where do I begin...? The boo and I did the Chef's Special 7 course meal, and loved it all!! I don't want to share too much because I want to be able to get a table here in the future, but damn, this is freaking amazing food.
author: Mari G.

description:
The tasting menu may have been one of the best meals I've had in SF. I hope to get back there soon to try some of the menu options. It's a little hard to spot and isn't high profile, but it's definitely a hidden gem of the Mission. Great low-key place to impress a date. 

Another review had issues with the spam and egg dish. I thought it was one of the highlights of the meal. It seemed to be a house-made ham patty, with a perfectly cooked soft-boiled egg, breaded, fried, topped with sesame and served with greens and avocado puree.
author: Mike O.

description:
Prubechu is a restaurant in San Francisco that serves delicious Chamorro food, providing a very satisfying dining experience for both newcomers who have never tried food from Guam and the CNMI, and for veterans who will appreciate the unique take on Chamorro Cuisine that Prubechu offers here.

As someone who grew up on Guam, I was excited to hear from my friends about a Chamorro restaurant opening right here in San Francisco, and visiting Prubechu was one of my first experiences in San Francisco after moving here.

The restaurant itself is very small, and is located a short walk away from the BART station on Mission St, between 24th and 25th streets. Inside can be a bit crowded at times, especially for events such as the screening of "Talent Town" in San Francisco by the Muña Bros., so I would recommend making a reservation in advance if you want to be guaranteed a seat.

If you are a veteran to consuming Chamorro food, please leave your expectations of cheap fiesta-style platters, with large servings of food, and a buffet-style presentation at the door. Prubechu demonstrates a focus on quality and service, and has an atmosphere reminiscent of the Islands. You can tell that Shawn and Shawn (both owners and one the head chef) do their best to serve delicious Chamorro food to the Bay area, and as a Chamorro diaspora Prubechu does an outstanding job. You almost feel like you are back on Guam or the CNMI when you eat here, they even play classic Chamorro music here! Then... you feel the cold outside and remember that this is Chamorro cuisine being served in San Francisco!

If you are new to consuming Chamorro food, Prubechu is a fantastic introduction into the cuisine commonly consumed in Guam and the CNMI, and in its own right is a fine dining establishment. Appreciate the cuisine it for what it is (Chamorro food), rather than thinking about it as a variation or knock off of something you may have tried before (Mexican, Asian, Filipino, etc.), and you'll likely enjoy this food! 

I usually order from the ala carte menu when I dine here since I come often by myself, mostly the empanada (Chamorro style), kelaguen månnok (chicken kelaguan), tinaktak (beef with coconut milk and, here at Prubechu, served with egg noodles), and hineksa' agå'ga (red rice). 

After eating here regularly for several months, I have yet to find anything that I do not like, and I look forward to Prubechu's evolution into the place for Chamorro food here in the Bay area.

Biba Prubechu! Bei bisita sesso' i fañochuyan este!
author: Alexander S.

description: Best tasting menu in SF. Worth every penny. These guys are the real deal. Perfect date spot.
author: Brian L.

description: All of the small cuisines on the Chef's tasting Menu was delicious! I would definitely recommended this place to go on a date or catch up with a couple of friends. Luckily, my boyfriend and I were able to get seated right way because it was getting really pack so I recommend on making a reservation beforehand.
author: Wednesday D.

description:
This place was really impressive. The food is very original (if you are not accustomed to Guam's cuisine) and really tasty. From the outside, it is unassuming, but you walk in and have a great experience. 

I would highly recommend the reasonably priced tasting menu. Other reviewers mention $40, but I think they raised it to $50, which is still well worth it for the 6 course meal. Interestingly, *none* of the dishes on the tasting menu are on the regular menu, so order the tasting menu, sit back, relax, and get ready for an adventure.

Our tasting (sounds like it varies every night; what came out was a surprise even to the waiter!):
Chalakilis toasted rice porridge - favorite dish
Motsiyas chicken sausage - tasty, nice spicy sauce on side to give it a kick
Frittata cappellini
Smoked pork jerky - cool dish
Local dungeness crab - close second favorite
Guam ice cream - tastiest dessert I have had in a while!

The owners and waiters are genuinely Guamanian, and specifically Chamorros (be sure to read the wikipedia page on Guam before you go).
author: Mike G.

description:
Food was incredible and unlike anything I've had before. Had the tasting menu, and they adjusted it to vegetarian (vegan would also be easy to do). 

Server was absolutely lovely. Will be back again hopefully soon.
author: Annabelle L.

description: This place was awesome with great tasting food and amazing staff. I was greeted with a warm smile and immediately offered a table for my group. Our group had the Tasting Menu and the staff was very helpful in explaining each selection. Each plate was very unique and fresh with an incredible taste. The space is definitely very intimate, warm, inviting, and in a perfect for location in The Mission District. Absolutely coming back!
author: Jose M.

description:
It was indeed a very good experience to finally get to try this much lauded place, and the tasting menu was quite an experience. Unusual ingredients used in imaginative ways, great presentation, and friendly service all made this memorable. Unfortunately the timing of the dishes was not ideal, with long waits between some of the courses. 

And with the price of the tasting menu creeping up from $40 to $50 and now $65 (!!), and a very small selection on the regular menu, I'm afraid I've been priced out of coming again. Frankly I couldn't afford it to begin with. Perhaps it's a supply and demand thing, but I fear these guys will not endure the divergence between the humble neighborhood and rootsy background of the food  and the super highbrow prices. Still, glad to have had the experience.
author: Daniel S.

description: I was thoroughly surprised how excellent and delicious the food was. I believe this is one of the best restaurants in the Bay Area, the tastes are phenomenal! Beef tinaktak was sublimely and uniquely delicious. The potato soup, the pork belly with smoked pork and charred veggies were also excellent. Can't wait to try other dishes here and do the tasting menu. This is a "must go" restaurant.
author: Dave N.

description: Aaaaamazing food. We had a six course meal here and every dish was incredible. The flavors were totally different, innovative, complex, just incredible. I docked one star for the ambiance because it feels a lot cheaper than the price of the food would suggest. The ceiling was stained and had cobwebs and the chairs looked like they were taken from Dunder Miffelin, but holy moly does the food ever make up for it all. Once these guys really get going and they do some minor renovations this place will be perfection.
author: Nat V.

description:
Delicious food, great service, solid beer selection, and killer a Island vibe. I Love this place! And to think, I've been passing it all this time on my way to La Taqueria. 

Parking sucks though, so be prepared to circle or walk. Also, could be pretty hard to find unless you're really looking. Would really benefit from a sign of some sort IMO, but whatever, Ill be back... Lots.
author: John V.

description: Went here last night to meet an old friend in town for business. The casual environment inside had me concerned at first, but my fears were allayed with excellent service - and food.  Not knowing much about Guamian (I think that is the adjective for food from Guam), we elected to do the tasting menu ($65). 5 savory and one sweet dish, one after the other after the other, we thought we were done but alas the shortrib one was excellent, as was the encrusted egg, as well as the soup come to think of it. My friend's second wine selection wasn't upto snuff, and they happily replaced it with another choice.  Definitely a gem.
author: Matt B.

description: Hard to find Chamorro restaurants in the Bay Area so I was excited to try this place when a friend told me about it. Not only was the food delicious, but the service was excellent. I personally think my mom's cooking is by far the best Chamorro food I've ever tasted, but this place comes pretty close. I look forward to my next visit and recommend you try it if you've never had Chamorro food before.
author: J S.

description:
have you ever been intimidated by a restaurant? Perhaps from seeing nothing but rave reviews and the fact that your good friend has been anticipating all year to go to this place, feelings of "woah...this place must be something"? that is what happened to this cat as he found himself stepping into this unique restaurant, and not being sure what to expect.

two friends and myself decided to try their tasting menu as it had 5 courses of different unique dishes to try. this ended up being one of the most amazing dining experiences of my life. 

one by one, our servers brought out these unique dishes and proceeded to explain in great detail exactly what each dish was, and how it was prepared. What I loved was that it seemed that each server truly knew what went into the preparation of the food and description, and they weren't just reciting a memorized list of things. definitely could tell the servers had just as much love for the food as the chef. 

every item we sampled was truly unique and filled with flavors I had never tasted before. it was really a refreshing twist to the kinds of places I usually step paw into. Yes prices are a bit on the high side, but this is so worth it to try a new kind of food that is expertly crafted, and a wonderful experience with the staff. 

I'll always remember my trip here! 

*chirp!*
author: Jei C.

description:
We liked this place. Given the crazy inconvenience of trying to park in this part of the Mission, not sure if we'll ever make it back here any time soon. But yeah, the food was definitely memorable and pretty good value.

We had the tasting menu... pretty ingenious that the chefs here can pull this type of menu off without having access to either a stove or an oven (they use induction hot plates to do everything). But not having either means that they also don't have a vent so the restaurant was crazy hot. And not having either means that ironically a lot of the food is cooked ahead and then re-heated and therefore not that hot.

That said, each course of the menu was better than the last. It started off kinda shaky with a warm oyster, but kept getting better and better until it finished with that wonderful coconut ice cream (still thinking about it). We were impressed by the unfamiliar taste profiles and the creativity of a lot of the dishes.

If we come again we'll try some of the entrees which also looked quite good. The service was a bit uneven and the pace of service a bit off, but I'm confident that these guys will work out the kinks and make this restaurant into a local favorite. That might involve getting rid of the tasting menu (probably more suited to a different kind of restaurant) and just focusing on entrees. So if you're into a taste adventures you better try this place before this option disappears.
author: Art C.

description:
Hmmm I really hate giving less than 4 star recommendations to new restaurants trying to make it in this cut throat foodie city, but I'd hate myself if I wasn't fair and objective in my review. 

Thus, I think Prubechu earns a solid 3 stars. However, with a few tweaks and changes, it definitely has a lot of potential to warrant 4 or even 5 stars. 

Prubechu was our choice for a Valentine's dinner this year. We were looking for something low-key, intimate and adventurous in the Mission so voila! The restaurant is very casual yet still manages to maintain an air of classiness - it's quite small so I'm sure once the word gets out, it'll start to get quite busy. The waiter was definitely very friendly and answered all of our questions about Guam-cuisine. 

However, my two peeves were 1) the slow service and 2) the actual food itself

The restaurant only has a prix fix menu - 5 courses for $40. It's definitely a steal price-wise as there are several amuse bouches not accounted for in the 5 courses. However, we had very mixed feelings about the courses. 

The first course (Egg with avocado, caramelized soy and salmon): delicious! The texture, flavor and presentation were all flawless 

The second course (chicken keleguan with coconuts, scallions and titiyas): the dressing was a bit intense and the flavor, although abundantly apparent, was just a bit too overwhelming and confusing 

The third course (shrimp patty with corn and peppers): solid. However, nothing to write home about. I've had similar shrimp patties in mediocre seafood restaurants

The fourth course (Chalakilis with porridge, anchovy, quail egg and pork): so I loved individual elements of this dish. The pork is well made. The quail egg was delicious. The porridge texture was great. The anchovy was raw and could have been good on its own. However, when combined, it was a very confusing mix with so many implosions of different flavors. 

The fifth course (kadu with shortrib, rice, potatoes, bean sprouts and peas): yum. This was definitely one of the highlights, second to the opener. The shortrib was well cooked and the texture was perfect. 

I think the slow service could be attributed to the fact that they had just recently opened a month before we went and were understaffed for Vday. As for the food, there were too many flavors floating around - they just need to be refined in a consumable manner. 

However, for $40, it's definitely worth checking out. And I see a lot of potential. 

Happy Eating, Yelpers!
author: Priya S.

description:
We tried this place on Saturday night after reading the yelp reviews. My boyfriend and I are "foodies" and doubted this restaurant could live up to all of the hype. We ordered the 5 course tasting option. OMG !!!! Every single dish was a new delight, it was FANTASTIC. One of the dishes had "spam" in it. I thought ick I hate spam. I've never been so glad to be so wrong. They make their own and it is delicious. If my boyfriend didn't eat faster than I do I would have eaten all of it :-) 

We live in Cupertino and wander around the city 3-4 times a month. We have had really good food in several restaurants. But this place is hands down one of the best in the city. The kitchen is open and we walked by and THANKED the chefs for the great meal before we left. The staff is very friendly & welcoming. We cannot wait to go back.
author: Lori D.

description:
We've been here 6x now and love it.  Opened in Feb by two friends, Shawn & Shawn, who's dream was to start a restaurant serving their native food.  Both guys were friendly, attentive, and very happy to answer all our questions about Chamarro food.  

This Tasting Menu is always amazing. They experiment with different ingredients and flavors so the dishes are either completely different or modified for a twist on the last time. 

My fave: the porridge with quail egg and pork -- interesting flavors (a hint of sourness like Kim Chi + a brief, spicy kick) and I really liked the texture (almost like oatmeal).  Reminded me of rice porridge my dad used to make when I got sick as a kid.

Great vibe and fun atmosphere on a Saturday night.  We ate from 8-10pm and had an awesome time.  Walked home full and happy!

Tip: they also have a big table which is great for parties. We hosted a birthday with 20 people and it was perfect. You can walk to Urban Putt afterwards!
author: Anh D.

description:
This is a great restaurant! It definitely lived up to the hype, and I hope it opens back up soon. 

I went in November on a last-minute date night.  I ordered the whole parrotfish, which was on the pricey side but very fresh, tender and flaky. Plus it had a bright blue beak! If you're not ready to plunk down ~$30 for a fish dish, there are many other great things on the menu. The real stars of the show were the appetizers and sides--empanadas, red rice, potato soup. Everything was delicious and well-portioned for two.

I'm not a stickler for service, and overall, I felt the service was on par with other high quality restaurants in the area. Our waiter told us a bunch of stuff about Guam and the history of the food we were eating. He got very excited and enthusiastic which was endearing. I left full and happy.
author: Lucy D.

description: Amazing tasting menu. Super unique take on South Pacific Cuisine (Chamorran, aka the people/culture of Guam). Great service as well. Honestly, it's such a straightforward, simple, experience with complex flavors and dishes, not much else to say. Pricey but this is one of those places you get what you pay for. Great for special occasions. Hafa Adai bra!
author: J D.

description:
Great service, good food, poor air quality. 

After seeing all the glowing reviews, I decided to bring 7 of my friends here visiting from out of town. The restaurant is pretty narrow and had two long tables set up for large parties and 4 small single top tables. For large parties, it's mandatory that everyone gets the $40 five course prefix menu. 

None of us had ever had Chamorro food so it was awesome when our server was very knowledgable and detailed in the explanation of each dish. I enjoyed 4 out of the 5 on the tasting menu. 

Worst dish - fried sardines on eggplant 
Best dish - coconut ice cream with pieces of these delicious chewy pieces described as tapioca patties roasted in banana leaf. I could've eaten 5 courses of this dish alone. 

The open kitchen did not seem like a real kitchen. There was a line of table top hot plates and no vent to suck out the fumes. At one point, some spicy peppers were being cooked and everyone at our table started coughing. I would not recommend coming here if you have plans after dinner because you will smell.
author: Lisa Q.

description:
Prubechu continues to deliver again and again. We've been probably once every other month or so, introducing our friends to this fantastic restaurant. The food is delicious, Shawn is incredibly friendly and helpful, and the ambiance is cozy and unpretentious. 

Their tasting menu goes through a regular rotation, so every time we come there are at least two or three new additions or changes. I can't recommend Prubechu highly enough.
author: Andy J.

description:
This may be one of the most underrated restaurants in SF. The food is delicious and perfectly paced. I've only ever had the tasting menu, and I can only recommend it to anyone. Also, the wine menu is short, but a great selection. 

Last time, we had: 

Coconut tortilla amuse buche
Corn soup with padron pepper 
Sort-of-scotch egg (which was perfect with guacamole and salad)
Beef tendon salad (maybe the most controversial of the bunch. Yummy though. I'd eat it again)
Smoked pork dish that I can't quite describe but which had an amazing purée associated with it
Rock cod with eggplants and potatoes and baby kale (like really baby not what you get elsewhere) and garlic flowers. This was amazing. 
That's when the dessert came. Strawberry with a wonderful flower and some vanilla cream. The memory gets somewhat blurry because of the large quantities of excellent wine we had. 

Must go now. Digest. Yummy.
author: Martin W.

description: The food was so amazing and the staff (who own the restaurant with the chef) were also the nicest! Everyone owes it to herself to go!
author: Jason C.

description:
Hafa adai! This spot was the business!

The restaurant opened up a couple days before I ate there, and my boyfriend, who spent his high school years on Guam wanted to go for our anniversary and a half.

The owners and chef Shawn and Shawn, and other chef Samir were so attentive and nice and friendly and you could tell they were so passionate and in love with what they were doing. 

The meal itself has honestly been one of my favorites in all of San Francisco! Everything was delicious and so well prepared. Plus, it was so unique! I've never had the dishes that my boyfriend often reminisced about (Chicken Keleguan, Red Rice, etc) and finally got to try them all with this new, fusion-y, San Francisco feel about it.

We got one tasting menu (Egg, Chicken Keleguan, Shrimp Patty, Chalakilis, and Kada) and an order of the a-la-carte Red Rice and Pork (Belly) and the Tinaktak (ground beef) Over Capellini. Everything was so flavorful and great!

Will definitely be coming back here and it's so awesome to see Guam food coming to the city! They're also playing the best island jams here so come hungry and leave happy!

Buen Prubechu!
author: Vickie D.

description:
I had no idea what guamanian food might be when i read inside scoop (sfgate.com) about new restaurant prubechu, I did recognize the chef owner as a protege of manny ramirez of palace fame and samir as the sous chef for the same accomplished former owner of roxie's on mission, which prubechu has taken over.

So i made a reservation via text message, and you should too because the restaurant is crowded with well wishers, friends and relatives clamoring to taste the upscale island cuisine. We opted for the 5 course tasting menu for $40, figuring this would provide a foodie short course on what was on offer.

A miyagi oyster with aged coconut vinegar (!) was the first amuse bouche, and a fine start. Much better than a traditional mignionette, the vinegar enhanced the briny succulence of the oyster without overpowering the seaside flavor. Really excellent in quality and composition.

Next followed an 8-minute egg sliced in half and flavored with carmelized soy and an avocado puree. Outstanding! I am now in love with carmelized soy and will be using it to enhance my eggs, meats, vegetables and whatever else i can concoct. The soy avocado combo would be a vast improvement on the typical mexican dip, watch out guacamole you're going guamanian in my house!

Prubechu does serve beer and wine, pbr, lagunitis and anchor steam for you beer drinkers. I knew the Justin cabernet on offer and chose that in favor of the pinot, chardonnay and savignon blanc. Wine choices were solid, i talked to the waiter, former employee of olivier's butchery in the dogpatch, about the choices and he was well versed. In fact, when questioned, he knew every ingredient and how it was prepared in every item we ate that night. Kudos for excellence in service.

Chicken keleguan was shredded chicken and scallions, shredded coconut and spices atop a coconut flatbread. A sort of guamanian tostada. I liked it, would make a great light lunch, especially with fruit.

A traditional guam style shrimp cake was elevated in another course featuring shrimp, corn and peppers served souffle style in tiny tart cups. Light yet savory, a few perfect bites.

Pork belly played a starring role, crispy and smoked, in chalakilis, a rice porridge with quail egg and achiote. This would be an excellent breakfast dish.

Next to last, and certain to top off your tank, was the kadu, a luscious shortrib stew with peas, potato, glass noodles and mung bean sprouts. Almost a halo halo stew, thankfully not sweet. Perfect for a cold, rainy night.

Dessert was a lovely, refined green coconut/tahitian vanilla ice cream. Flecks of vanilla floating through the creamy concoction.

I really enjoyed the culinary tour of guam and even more so, all of the fellow diners who added to the evening with explanations of guam and much shared camaraderie. Definitely make your way to prubechu and enjoy the social as well as the gustatory aspects of this fine new debut.

The interior of prubechu is warm and stylish, an amazing feat considering the surely skimpy budget of a start up restaurant. We really loved the whole experience, prices are outstanding for the quality, and staff is happy to share details about the food even while bustling for the growing crowd.

Best wishes to all!
author: Kelly K.

description:
Very unique experience. We were a group of 6 and we had two vegetarians. The restaurant was able to make a special menu for them as we all tried the tasting menu. Each course was interesting. There was a spam and eggs, coconut soup with ham, chicken sausage, a beef dish, and a coconut rice dessert. The only con would be the price. It was $65 for the tasting menu and the drink menu wasn't that impressive. 

It was a first in terms of cuisine--food from Guam!
author: Sri C.

description:
Shawn^2, you guys are awesome!

My gf and I fell in love with Roxie's Cafe last year after stumbling onto it via a Groupon deal. We had our hearts broken when we discovered that the place had closed after only being able to visit it once.... but luckily, I stumbled upon some food blog that mentioned that the place was being reincarnated as a Guamanian joint!

I had a couple friends in college that were straight off of Guam, but I've never really experienced their cuisine, so I didn't really know what to expect. Shawn (one of two) told us that their cuisine has influences from Spain, US, Japan, and a slight bit of Pilipino. That odd combination of cultures sure did not disappoint when it came to the flavor palate.

The $40 tasting menu was totally worth it. 5 courses, an amuse bouche, and a dessert. The sous vide egg with asparagus and homemade rice crackers were amazing -- almost Californian, with a perfectly soft-boiled egg, and a nice texture contrast with the rice crackers. Their porridge -- oh my god, it was amazing at Roxie's and it's still amazing now -- they use 3 different "grinds" of toasted rice using a coffee grinder, and use all sorts of unique ingredients to taste the most amazing porridge I've ever had. Their beef short rib with noodles and a soy coconut broth -- I literally licked the bowl clean! Don't forget about their coconut ice cream -- I actually HATE coconut, but I couldn't get enough of this ice cream. Buttery and sweet, with toasted hazelnuts... the other Shawn said that it was their play on the Bi-Rite salted caramel. I think it's better than Bi-Rite!

Needless to say, I love the chill vibe of the place, the friendly staff, and most importantly, the amazing food. You should all try it!


tl;dr - GO AND GET THEIR TASTING MENU


Sidenote: Apparently, SF Chronicle's Michael Bauer just released a review of this place today, and he seems to think that it has a lot of potential -- http://www.sfgate.com/restaurants/diningout/article/Review-Prubechu-Flavors-of-Guam-with-a-loving-5397122.php (a food rating of 2.5 stars by Bauer is actually very very comendable)
author: Kazu O.

description:
I'm so glad that I came here during my visit to SF! The owners are super welcoming and incredibly nice -- we spent about 15 minutes talking about the history of Guam and what brought them to San Francisco. 

I would highly recommend the Chef's Tasting Menu! You get a story and explanation with every dish, and the courses are all very different and well made. It's very apparent that they put a lot of love and pride onto their food. We had everything from oysters and fried calamari to homemade spam and pork belly to coconut ice cream. I had never tried Guam food before but after eating here, I definitely want to try more!
author: Tracey H.

description: Cute place, food was good.   I have not had food from Guam so it was a little unusual.  Staff friendly & nice.  However, I found it a little odd a credit card was required for a reservation.  We were literally the only diners in the restaurant.  I normally pass on restaurants which require a credit card reservation. Seems this place could use all the business It can get (& deserves).  I would change this policy if I were them
author: Ed F.

description:
I seldom write reviews but I would like to first say that what Prubechu has done and what it offers is a unique and fantastic opportunity to experience a delicious, although obscure, cultural cuisine. 

I did the tasting menu and I ordered the red rice for the table to try as a nod to my festive Chamorro roots. This was a good amount of food, and although I am no culinary auteur, I did think that each dish in the tasting menu were unique and tasty and a breath of fresh air from all the American contemporary I've been accommodating lately. Hilights include the chicken kelaguen (their flatbread was delicious--I wanted a complete order of that alone lol), the succulent meat atop the porridge, the donni and finedene, and of course the Kadu. 

As a Chamorro, I see this restaurant as an achievement. You will rarely see a Chamorro cuisine anywhere outside of Guam, and certainly not presented with a gourmet flair. And so to me it is a fantastic way to share our cultural foods and what they represent. When I ate here I could not help but feel so proud as flavors of certain meats transported me back to barbecues at my uncle's house, and the slurp of soups reminded me of my younger brother's favorite dish at home. Proud to have my friends visit this place and experience something that matters more and more to me as I get older. 

Why the four stars? Only because I believe they can do even more and I look forward to the restaurant's evolution and growth. 

Side story:
Six years ago I was rocking my Guam shirt at Bruno's right around the corner and a guy stops me and asks if I was from Guam. We get to talking and i remember him wearing a baseball cap in the club, that he was a student at the culinary academy in the city, and that his name might have been Shawn. 

My coworker tells me about Prubechu and we immediately make plans to eat here a few days later and I walk in to see a sou chef, the host, and the head chef...rocking a baseball cap. It was Shawn. He had actually opened a Chamorro restaurant in San Francisco. How amazing to see things like that come full circle and be a part of it.
author: Edward K.

description:
The minute you walk through the doors, the smell of smoked pork will greet you. It'll start making you hungry.

We opted to do the tasting menu. 

First was an amuse bouche of raw oyster shooter. Very refreshing. 

1st course was a cooked egg with some fixings. Not bad but a little salty. 

2nd course was the chicken kelegeun which was shredded chicken with spices on a flatbred. That was good. It would be good for light lunch or snack. 

For our 3rd course, we were supposed to have a shrimp patty soufflé but for some reason we didn't get it and they substituted some other vegetarian dish.  That was not to my liking. It had pickled cucumbers, some other vegetables and a dollop of crème fraiche. That was way too salty. I could have passed on that. 

I don't remember the names here on out, but 4th course was this smoked pork dish on some pureed starch. That was my favorite. The pork was very flavorful and savory. I could have eaten a large bowl of that for a meal. 

5th course was a dish of meat, rice, and vegetables served in a broth. That tasted like some comfort food that you would eat at home.

Last course was homemade ice cream and coconut shavings. That was really good. I enjoyed that.

Be sure to ask about the wine prices before ordering. It's not listed on the menu and we found out a bottle cost more than the price of the 1 pre-fixe tasting menu.  

Service here was very friendly. Our server and the owner and the chef came over to our table. They were very personable and gave us explanations on the dishes.
author: Kenson K.

description:
I wanted to like Prubechu - I really did. 

Visited the joint with my SO and tried the tasting menu. Most of the dishes were both tasty and unique, but neither of us founded the majority of what we ate to be anything more than pretty good. The problem for us was that the dishes didn't seem to compliment each other or show any kind of subtly -- almost every dish was super flavorable and very much the opposite of subtle. 

Then we got the bill, and I couldn't help but feel I'd had dozens of more delicious and cheaper, or at least equally priced, dinners (+drinks).
author: Ben G.

description:
First time having Guamanian food, I'd never even heard of this place when a friend suggested it while we were out in the mission. What a find!

I love spam and eggs, but it'll never be the same for me after I've had their version. It was so good, I didn't even look for rice!

I just wish they had the option for a 3 or full course tasting menu, because while I scarfed everything down, I was way too full for the last course.

Thanks to the staff for a wonderful experience!
author: Michelle Y.

description:
We moved in up the street and were taken here by some new neighbors. We have since been back and bring people here when visiting. It is great. 

The food is tasty, the atmosphere relaxed and the owners/staff are passionate about the food.
author: Neil A.

description:
I'm not familiar with Chamorro food so I had a great time learning about and trying the cuisine of Guam. We went with the tasting menu (very affordable!) for a casual sampling of dishes. I liked the shrimp patty with corn, the escabeche, and even all the coconut (which I usually don't) in the various dishes. I wasn't too fond of the porridge though, but maybe that's because I don't like it to begin with. Our server was really fantastic and took the time to explain each dish and answer any questions. He was also very informative and not at all condescending, which was really appreciated.

All in all, it's a great experience and for me, a chance to try a new cuisine. Would I return here all the time? Probably not. It's more a place I would go to every now and then and a place to take adventurous foodies.
author: Allison S.

description:
Guamanian food? Who knew it was so Damn delicious! 
Went in on a whim, trying something totally new and we were definitely impressed with the warm and friendly service (thank you for the history lesson of Guam, so great to get an education while eating tasty food!)

We tried the pickles (oh so good!!!), the soup, ceviche and the red rice plate...everything was fantastic. 
Prices are very reasonable and the ambiance is comfortable and warm. 
It felt like a mini vacation. 

Great experience.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I have no idea what the people who gave this place less than 5 stars were thinking!!  I brought several very critical international foodies to this spot last night and the food was amazing!  The presentation, the flavors, and the owners were all amazing.  This is a 10 for me in San Francisco!  

I was really hesitant on a tasting menu since I and another at the table had some food restrictions, but the way they worked around them was fantastic.  you really should give this place a try, you won't regret it!  I will say the 5 courses, each one is relatively small, but the food adds up and by the end you are totally satisfied.
author: Josh R.

description:
Sorry to leave such a poor review on a small establishment...I've been very hesitant to review...but...here it goes:

:::POOR VALUE:::
:::FLAVORS ARE NOT BALANCED:::
:::MORE PRESENTATION THAN TASTE:::

Their pre fix menu style dining of dining at $55 is seemed kinda cheap...but then again, I realized why...

Some of the plates I remember being served:
1. Flat bread with butter and yogurt sauce - size of my fingernail thumb.  ARE you serious?  It was about the 1/4 size of a triscuit!  It's just flatbread.  it tasted good.  But why give each person 1/4 size of something and put it on an individual plate and call it one of the courses.  This is how our meal started......I was thinking okay...palate cleanser...but no....

2. Rice porridge with boiled egg with runny yolk...or at least some of us had runny yolk.  This was a much larger portion.  But rice is also cheap.  My biggest gripe with this course was the temperature.  The porridge wasn't hot...it was kinda luke warm....ALMOST warm.  it'd be nice to have it served hot and not have it congeal in front of me as I tried to eat it.

3. Some broth with A mussel and house cured pork...SWEET?  doesn't work.  This is where i confirmed that they don't know how to balance flavors.  Way to sweet.  Again, this dish wasn't hot nor cold.  At this point I felt like I was being served cafeteria food...

4. Some food with green sauce on the plate that tasted like crab but there was no crab in it.  Piece of over dried pork, again cured in house.  Tasted like eating a corner piece of meat that was sitting out on the counter for 2 days.  *Sigh*

5. Dessert, the finisher, my boyfriend said this was the worst part of the meal.  TWO TINY pieces of tapioca that was dry, with a hint of sweetness, that summed up to the size of my pinky finger.

Our table had 3 bottles of wine and that still left us critical about the meal.  My friend asked if we could go to Dr Teeth down the street because they have good chicken wings...

After $90/pp, I felt bad for picking the place and felt like I wasted a nice dinning experience with friends.  Could've gone accross the street to Rosamunde for a beer and weiner.  

Sorry Purbechu...you royaly sucked.
author: Janet L.

description:
Wow. This place has got to be the city's best kept secret. At least for now. Everyone at our table got the $40 tasting menu...and we sounded like we were having an orgy. "Mmmm ahhh ooohhh so good mmmm oh myyy godddd...." After. Every. Dish. Didn't someone smart and profound say something about how good food is like good sex?

Needless to say, we were blown away by the quality of the ingredients (Dirty Girl Produce and shipped directly from Guam), the visual appeal and preparation of each dish, and the perfectly in-sync flavors. 

Now, let's talk about the flavors you may encounter. First, there is spicy...the Chamorros don't kid around with the hot stuff. They have their own kickass hot sauce that is very spicy (you've been warned). Then there is sour...as in tangy coconut vinegar liquor. I didn't even know this existed! And then there is creamy coconut to whisk you away to a white-sand beach on a deserted island...well at least in your mind. Spicy, tangy, creamy, with a bit of soy umami, and some smokiness too....definitely a sexy party.

$40 seems like an incredible deal for what we got: 6 dishes (including a dessert) + an raw oyster amuse. We also ordered the pickles and keleguan. Though they were good, they paled in comparison to the tasting menu dishes. This review is already too long, so I'll just mention a few highlights from our tasting dishes: sous-vide quail egg, achiote porridge, smoked pork belly, pork jerky, soy-coconut broth, perfect spring peas, okra, eggplant, morels, COCONUT CANDY ICE CREAM.

Our meal took almost 3 hours, so don't be in a rush. This place is easy to miss...look for the faded Roxy's Cafe sign. Credit cards accepted (via Square). Counter area overlooking the open kitchen area for walk-ins. Tables can be combined for large parties. Can get loud (see first paragraph).
author: Carolyn F.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in all of SF. Delicious fresh food that tastes unlike anything else in the city. Highly recommend the chicken dish (I can't spell anything lol) and the veggie curry dish. Red rice is also a must. Also, stellar beer list. We'll for sure be back.
author: Matthew Z.

description: We are probably going to make this spot our regular dineling spot. Their Chef's choice Tasting menu is super awesome!!!  It's dishes that's not on the menu and it''s an opportunity to explore a variety of dishes all at once if you can't make a decision on anything on the menu.  A no brainer prefixed meal.
author: Anna F.

description: Had the tasting menu and man was it an amazing life changing experience! This was my first time having a 7 course meal and it's incredible! Although the price is a bit steep, I think maybe $50 is a bit more reasonable. But still very good!
author: Ciara A.

description: This place is incredible!. The food is amazing and creative.  The hospitality is so warm and intimate.  Love the island style with gourmet quality.
author: Who K.

description: Food was fine, pretty different, but definitely not 4.5 stars.  Had high expectations and it did not meet them. Found it to be pretty affordable though.
author: Rob S.

description:
POST REVIEW FOLLOW UP:  AFTER READING OTHER REVIEWS, I REALIZED THAT AS SOMEONE ELSE POINTED OUT, ALL OF THE GREAT REVIEWS ARE LIKELY FAKED AND PAID FOR.  READER BEWARE...  GIVEN HOW AWFUL THE FOOD WAS (AND INCOMPETENT THE SERVICE WAS) I FELT LIKE I HAD GONE TO A COMPLETELY DIFFERENT RESTAURANT THAN REVIEWS AND REALIZE THAT IS THE CASE...

I really looked forward to trying this unique place.  Sounds very exotic and interesting.  And, they really try hard, bless their little hearts.  
But, the food was not only really bad but most sincerely very bad.  They tried to foist the tasting menu on us, but we resisted and ordered a la carte.  We tried a half dozen dishes.  They ranged from bland (green goddess romaine salad) to inedible (weird beef pasta).  Many dishes were not finished.  On top of it, we got the fish special which meant for $40 you got a tiny boiled whole fish with scales still all over it.  Really unappetizing.  
Luckily, by avoiding the tasting menu, we got out early enough to go down the street for a delicious post dinner quesadilla at that faithful cheap but cheerful standby El Farolito 2 mins away at Mission/24th.  You might keep that in mind...
author: Trecker J.

description:
Yet another Mission neighborhood hidden gem. A friend brought me here recently and I had no idea what to expect walking in. The ambiance is calm, intimate and welcoming. All of the employees greet you with a smile and you can tell they are truly happy to have you as their guest. 

The menu is very small, offering a tasting menu for $55 or simply ordering a few dishes. It is a little bit on the pricey side especially because the portions are small. But completely worth it because it is so delicious! I have never had food from Guam before, but each dish we had exploded with flavor. The combinations of ingredients in each plate are incredibly refined, I was thoroughly impressed. 

We started off by sharing the empanada and then split two dishes. One of the dishes was all vegetables (I cannot recall the name) and the other by our servers suggestion was the Tinaktak beef with house made cappellini noodles, coconut milk and vegetables. Almost all of their dishes had a coconut infusion but they blended a lot of citrus flavors into it as well. I've just never had food like this before and was so amazing how much I loved it! Every single plate we had was so yummy!

The other thing I really loved about the experience was that with each dish that came out, someone from the kitchen came and described the dish in detail and how it was prepared. There's nothing I love more than dining at a place that is passionate about their food! I will definitely be back here many more times, I want to try the tasting menu next!
author: Mandy A.

description:
I was absolutely crushed last winter when I heard that Roxy's cafe was closing.  Someone we had tried to recommend the restaurant to, tried to make a reservation and they were told that they were closed.  The next time we went out for drinks in that neighborhood we stopped by to take a look, and were delighted to see Shawn with a new restaurant Prubechu that highlighted Guamanian food.  Now what can bet better than Shawn X 2.  This as been on our must eat list for quite a while and we finally got around to trying it.

My favorite dish from Roxy's was the porridge, which to me was the classic comfort food.  So naturally we had to order the tasting menu as the porridge isn't available a la cart.  The $40 tasting menu featured an amuse bouche (oyster), salmon crude, asparagus with as sous vided egg, a dish that is a take on sweet and sour topped with fish, porridge with smoked pork and a quail egg, short ribs in a soy and coconut broth, and coconut ice cream topped with toasted hazelnut for dessert.  My all time favorite is the porridge.  Typically Chinese porridge has a different grain, whereas this one is very fine almost like polenta.  Shawn explained that they use roasted rice at different grinds to give it a unique texture.  This dish is the ultimate comfort food, especially with the perfectly poached quail egg on top.  My other favorite was the short rib was the soy and coconut broth and noodles.  Also a very homey dish.  Just when you thought things wouldn't get much better, they surprised us with complementary ice cream.  The ice cream had a perfect texture contrast with the coconut in the ice cream, the roasted hazelnut, and the ice cream itself.  

Also the service is amazing.  Really it's like going to Cheer's where everyone knows your name.  Although I was heart broken to know that Roxy's had closed, I'm so glad to have Prubechu in the neighborhood.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Good service, fantastic food, and fun atmosphere. I feel like I walked into my Aunt's kitchen and she's making me a family dinner. I will definitely be coming back to try their other dishes. The red rice was made to perfection! I'm so glad to have found this restaurant. Hafa adai!
author: Jinnie L.

description: Back again for business but could not resist coming back for a lil taste of home.  Tasting menu was amazing as the last time - however, if ur craving the usual fiesta-ish grub - I would opt for the ala carte options as our coursed meal did not have red rice! Awesome grub tho and I'm psyched these guys are doing well in such a competitive foodie city. Prubechu was still "cherry" nai. Still cherry... Be back soon.
author: Lor B.

description:
I went to eat dinner at this place with a friend who spent significant part of his life in Guam. He absolutely adored the food. I too loved the food and the friendly service. Since there were four or us, we ordered one of everything on the menu and four drinks. It came to 37$ per person, so I guess it could have been teeny bit cheaper, but hey the food is great. 

My favorites are turmeric pickled daikon, potato soup, Golai hagan suni and tinaktak. Golai hagan suni is eggplant cooked in coconut milk and other veggies and it is absolutely fabulous. The salad is adequate and I did not care for the pulled chicken titiyas and the dried grilled pork...meh. The only dessert they had on the menu is coconut candy icecream. OMG absolutely fabulous. 

Considering everything, it is worth trying a few times. It also seems like a good place to take a date to.
author: Balu V.

description:
$70 for Palaksi (parrot fish)!!!
I was extremely excited to eat at Prubechu.  I am Chamorro and was thrilled at the fact that there is such a restaurant.  Sadly, my family and I were very disappointed.  $70 for palaksi (parrot fish)?!?  Really?  At $4.99/per pound at the Asian market, they are not embarrassed to charge $70 for our parrot fish that was no more than 2 pounds.  I've never had a problem paying market price for seafood, which is usually no more than $35-$40 so we didn't even ask what the price for the parrot fish was.   Lesson learned...we will start asking now so we don't ever get ripped off again.

We also had the tinaktak which is ground beef with green beans in coconut milk.  I grew up eating tinaktak and often cook it myself.  We've always eaten it over rice. At Prubechu, tinaktak is served with pasta.  Okay, I get that they are somewhat a "fusion" type of restaurant but when I asked if I could have rice instead of pasta, the answer was no.  Another disappointment.  I am a paying customer and wanted a taste of home, not some fancied up non-traditional taste of home.  Especially when you are so far away from home and crave true Chamorro food.

The shrimp keleguin was good but the portion was very small for the price. 

Our bill was $163.00 not including the tip and we were not even full.  We were still hungry and ended up going to get tacos & burritos at another restaurant.

I truly hope that Prubechu can stick to a more traditional Chamorro menu so that Chamorros who crave that taste of home (but are too busy at times to cook) can enjoy Chamorro food...and also, so that people of different ethnic backgrounds can truly taste and know just what Chamorro food is and just how delicious it is.  Being that there is only one Chamorro restaurant in San Francisco, there is no need to fancy it up and make it a "fusion" restaurant when our food is scrumptious all on its own...something to be proud of.
author: Kala C.

description: Fancy food in an unexpected setting. I'm not familiar with Guam cuisine so the experience was entirely new for me. The tasting menu offered some excellent dishes--poached egg porridge was quite tasty. Creamy and full of flavor. Most dishes had a lot of dimensionality with textures and flavors. There was one or two off the preset menu that weren't so impressive such as the clams which were just too salty and lacking anything special. Also the smoked pork was too tough, almost like eating beef jerky. My main complaint is that the portion is quite small. 5 courses later and I'm still hungry...our entire table still had a healthy appetite for more food.
author: Royce L.

description:
Before dining at Prubechu, I really didn't know what to expect. Being that my girlfriend is from Guam, the only Guamanian cuisine that I've had was from her cooking. Thus, when I realized that Prubechu opened up this year and was the first and only Guamanian restaurant in NorCal, we couldn't pass up a chance to go. No only was our own hype there, the amazing Yelp reviews further solidified the anticipation.

Prubechu is located on Mission between 24th and 25th. What I despise about the Mission is that it is incredibly hard to find parking here on the weekends. Luckily, within 5 minutes, I managed to magically find a spot around the block from the restaurant. When walking towards Prubechu, you might actually miss it because the sign is so incognito. As a frame of reference, it's next door to Quickly, which you absolutely won't miss. Upon stepping inside, you'll notice that Prubechu isn't a large restaurant by any means, but it sure is popular. Make sure to make a reservation beforehand, because I don't really see how you can snag a table otherwise.

Once we got seated, Shawn and his staff took care of us for our whole stay. For dinner, we decided to order:

- Pickles (seasonal vegetables): $5
- Chamorro Empanada: $7
- Kelaguen Manok: $12
- Tinaktak: $16
- Red Rice: $18
- Fried Fish: $22

Dessert:
