- Coconut Candy Ice Cream with Appigigi 

For starters, the picked vegetables served as a good opening. They included: mango, papaya, radish, kimchee, and more. There was a nice spicy tang to each vegetable, and had that fresh homemade touch to it. Next up were the Chamorro empanadas. These are incredibly different from the empanadas that you're usually used to. Inside these bad boys was rice, achote, and mana. The empanadas were so taste that we ordered 2 additional to go. 

If you're looking for some fresh tasting food, then the kelaguen is your dish of choice. This is Guamanian chicken ceviche with scallions and coconut, served on top of what resembles as a tortilla. Boy was this tasty. The chicken was juicy and combined with the citrus, it definitely made me want to order another round. If you're a coconut fan, then the tinaktak is for you. It comes served with homemade pasta. For my palate, it was a little on the thicker side, but I did enjoy the heavy coconut flavor that was associated with this dish.

Next up were the red rice and fried fish. Paired with these dishes was finedine, a vinegar based condiment. The red rice was paired with their homemade bacon, which was literally thick slab of pork. It was loaded with flavor, and the rice itself was moist. When combined with the fried fish, you have a winning entree. To finish off our dinner, we had their coconut candy ice cream with appigigi. The ice cream had a nice sea salt sprinkled on top, and when combined with the pieces of tapioca, it balanced the dish out, leaving me incredibly satisfied with my meal.

Throughout our meal, the service was attentive, the staff was incredibly nice, and of course the food was amazing. For Guamanian cuisine, there really isn't anywhere else you can go to in NorCal. Prubechu does the island a service by offering authentic tasting dishes to us Californians. Will I be back? You can bet on it.
author: Michael W.

description: Really amazing food and wonderful service! All the courses in the tasting menu are phenomenal. Amazing flavors. Great experience. I was new to Guamanian food but it has a wonderful fusion of flavors that works really, really well in California! Will be back and often.
author: Tom H.

description: I was traveling alone for work so I had the tasting menu aaaalll byyyyyy myyssseeelf, like Celine. It was unique and delicious, but the waiter had to coach me through my meal towards the end because it was so much food and I don't know the etiquette of quitting halfway through a tasting menu. With his support, I made it through all the courses without puking and left a very happy camper. The service was also exceptional.
author: Olga R.

description: Great and different food. The service and hospitality was outstanding. The host took time to explain to us the history of Guam. We arrived a bit late and could not do the tasting menu (9:45pm). So go early! The a la carte though was great. The Ceviche was fresh and different and tasty :)
author: Audrey L.

description: This was such a great experience! First, the people there are so nice and knowledgeable, and were really helpful as we picked out our food and drinks. You can tell that everyone there puts their heart into what they're creating, and it's evident in everything they serve. It was my first experience with Guamanian food, and I will definitely be returning. For this meal, I got the red rice as my entree and the pickles and empanadas as appetizers. I'll probably go for the tasting menu next time so I can try even more! Only downside is that I was too full for dessert:)
author: Audrey G.

description: Hidden gem in full view from Mission St. Incredible and authentic tasting menu, and friendly staff happy to talk about each dish and Guam's history in general. Coconut soup with Dungeness crab and Chicken Sausage in Banana leaf were our favorites.
author: Ken S.

description: Went here on a date and recommend splitting the tasting menu as we did. It was a nice way of getting a mix of 'adventurous' (and interesting) dishes. I loved their homemade spam and corn and shallot soup. Will have to come back to try their ceviche!
author: Hanah K.

description: Always unique, tremendous attention to detail and delicious. I have no clue why more people don't flock to here. Maybe it is better that way because we can still get in easily.
author: susie w.

description:
Very unique and delicious food. Somewhat latin, somewhat Hawaiian and somewhat Asian. 

I can't remember the name of the main dishes but we enjoyed all of it. Out of stuff I can describe, we really enjoyed the ceviche, the special cocktails, and most importantly, the very at tentative service. 

We did the a la carte thing but we will definitely be back for the tasting menu
author: Arjuna S.

description: Excellent service, even better food, homey atmosphere! What else could you ask for! Every dish was lick the plate good!!! Must try this place!!
author: Gerri G.

description:
Absolutely exceeded our expectations.  Don't let the modest decor fool you - this place is serving some spectacular food.  Well-thought out courses with presentations that will rival much more expensive peer restaurants.

One of the best meals I've had in SF in a while, to say nothing of the value (with our 5+ course meal costing just $55).

Will definitely return.  Hopefully soon.
author: Lance R.

description:
If you're looking for styrofoam fiesta plates, you came to the wrong place. 

Prubechu serves GOURMET Chamorro delicacies with flavors that are perfect, and it has an ambience of pride and the Hafa Adai spirit!
The tasting menu and a la carte menu are both phenomenal. 
Tasting menu - they like to switch it up, but each course is always better than the last.
A la carte - the empanadas, chicken kelaguen, and red rice dish were all on point.
Everything was served in a timely manner, and the owners and staff are super welcoming, chill, and Guam natives. Ask them anything :)
author: Dominique F.

description: superb, fascinating cuisine.  Chamorro food (from guam) is really interesting and fairly different than other South Pacific cuisines like Filipino, Hawaiian, etc..
author: Matt K.

description:
Stunning. This is what I call an Exquisite Dining Experience.

Prubechu is tucked unassumingly on bustling Mission St between 24th and 25th streets. Blink and you'll miss it. Its facade blends in with all the neighboring stores and restaurants. It looks even a little rundown, faded awning and letters peeling. It's not "fancy"; there's no modern decor or anything remotely close to stuffiness. It's homey and down-to-earth and welcoming. 

And the food will blow your mind.

I came here with my BF after trying to find something more unique than the standardly nice "Contemporary" or "New American" restaurants that seem to be popping up all over the place these days. Don't get me wrong, all the hip new places are lovely, but I was looking for something that would take my taste buds on journeys they've never been on. Prubechu did that and so much more.

We opted for the 5 course tasting menu (really 7 courses with amuse bouche + dessert). It was one of the best meals I have ever had. All of the flavors combinations were inventive and fresh, novel uses of familiar ingredients and novel uses of novel ingredients (juvenile goatfish?! cilantro flowers?!). Coconut was incorporated in almost every dish, savory and sweet. There was spice, and tartness, interesting textures and creative use of garnishing. I'm unfamiliar with Chamorro cuisine but the staff took time to explain every dish in detail, and the cultural importance of the ingredients. They get most of their ingredients directly from Guam and it is clear that they really are trying to share a piece of their home with their diners. Everything was incredible, I mmmmmm'd and aaaaaah'd and pretty much licked every plate clean. I will be back again and again for sure.

The atmosphere is so laid back. There was no rush, each course came out at a reasonable but very leisurely pace. Servers were attentive and friendly and always down to chat, but otherwise let you hang out for as long as you want. My BF and I had a wonderful time. It was intimate and relaxed, but the food was beautiful and top notch. 

I hope Prubechu and the lovely people who own and work here all do exceedingly well! For now though, it's a bit of a hidden gem, and I intend to take advantage of that to the fullest.
author: Carol C.

description: Great little spot! This was my first time and first time having Guam food. Food is so good! Went here for my Birthday dinner and everything was great. I had the chef tasting menu and it was really good. I will definitely be back.
author: Patrick M.

description:
This is not a place where you will get large portions (ie. burrito); This is a place for a sophisticated palate or well-developed palate. You should have a good appreciation of flavors. 

Both Shawns were awesome! Personable friendly and very informative. Can't wait to come back. Food was so on point - Flavorful, Great Balance, and Presentation. Definitely Michelin Star quality! 

More pork shoulder please! What am i saying? More of everything please...
author: Thomas C.

description:
A hidden gem (who knows for how long, though) in the Mission! I've not previously had the pleasure of dining upon cuisine from Guam, but if this restaurant is any indication, the country must be an island of earthly delights. Sean and the staff have taken a rather plain/dingy place and transformed it into a space that is cozy and friendly. The hospitality and the food are top notch -- we had the chef's tasting menu (a bargain for the price) and really enjoyed the spam and eggs, oxtail with with soy broth and calamari with melon and cucumber. There were other small courses as well -- they were all delicious. 

Looking forward to coming back to try the à la carte stuff!
author: Chris O.

description:
This place is phenomenal and one of SF's best kept secrets! I hesitate to write this review because I don't want the restaurant spoiled by legions of eager diners in line before me, but the chef is so kind and funny and hard-working, and the food is so damned delicious and beautiful, that I can't bear the thought of not sharing the good news. 

We three each got the tasting menu, which is--as my father would say--a bargain at twice the price. $45 for at least six courses. One of us eats no poultry at all and the other is lactose intolerant. The chef didn't blink at all and served us several delicious dishes, each to the right person with thoughtful substitutions. Everything looked so good I was tempted to invent a dietary restriction of my own to try something else the next time!

No need for dishonesty, though. It seems that the menu is constantly changing and there's always fresh food and preparations. Do not be put off by the unassuming front window; this place is a gem! Personal service, relaxed and casual atmosphere, five-star food and presentation, and a price point that'll make you think you're still in Kansas. What's not to love?
author: Athame E.

description:
hey All You Guamanians in the Bay Area Hiding Among the Many Filipinos Out There, it's time to rise as food from your culture has made it's way out of the comforts of your homes and into the mouths of anybody willing to give it a try! hooray, right? right! 

walking into the space that is Prubechu, you wouldn't think the quality or creativity in the dishes could be anything more than simple home cooking. the three counter top burners, ice cream freezer and portable deep fryers don't seem like they are capable of putting out five course meals for tables full of people but somehow they do. and it's not just sloppily thrown at you in a rushed fury or hurriedness. the dishes are thoughtfully prepared and executed. the service was relaxed, informative and enthusiastic. whether it was the cook or the host/server/probably part owner, there was a passion when speaking about the next course we were to indulge in. 

the food's base is Chamorro or in recognizable words, Guamanian comfort food. but then they take it to another level by using quality seasonal ingredients chosen on a daily basis at the farmers market and amp it up even more by making it pretty. the five course dinner is accompanied by an amuse (ours was a fancy pants oyster) and a dessert (ours was a coconut with rock salt ice cream with a tapioca/coconut concoction that was incredible) and costs a very reasonable $45. while the rest of the menu sounds great and I'll definitely be back to try it, I recommend the tasting menu upon your first experience. 

I thoroughly enjoyed my meal at prubechu!
author: Regina C.

description:
Amazing!

Small place with a big heart. Shawn and Shawn know what they're doing and it shows.

Go Now. Go Often.
author: David A.

description: We had the tasting menu and it was a disappointment after reading all the reviews here on Yelp. Bland tastes, boring textures, cheap ingredients. Nothing special at all really. Service ok but a bit slow for a place with this reputation.
author: Per L.

description: Brought some friends here to experience Chamorro cooking. The dishes were amazing! The tinaktak, BBQ meats and kelaguens were delicious. We also had the coconut dessert and loved it. Really enjoyed our visit and will definitely be going back!
author: Al T.

description:
I took my husband here. I think it's important to note that he's Italian and Chamorro.  A man who is use to some good cooking!

He had the Chief's tasting menu and I tried every dish.  Every time he tried the dishes, his eyes said it all-yum! I highly recommend this place, it was all very delicious. Next time we go, I'll be getting my own Chief's tasting!

I hope they get a bigger place in the future, we wouldn't be able to fit our big family.  And wear something light, it's warm inside.

See you again soon! 

Hafa Adai!
author: Katherine C.

description:
It was our second time here and we were not disappointed. I celebrated my birthday here a few months ago with 25 of my closest friends. I can say that the food and service are excellent for both. 

My husband and I shared the tasting menu and ordered items from the a la carte menu for our two boys and us to share. We ordered the shrimp kelaguen, chicken kelaguen, soft shell crab with veggies with coconut milk, red rice plate with smoked beef and pork belly, empanada and the beef tinaktak pasta. Our 12 year old ate everything except for the shrimp. We let them know ahead of time that he had a shellfish allergy. 

The tasting menu was different than when we were here in June and just had to order. My husband was blown away by the deep fried 6 minute egg (with a little Panko) with aioli over a sliced tomato and okra and chili pepper and house made spam. Didn't get to try the house made spam as our 12 year old snatched it right up. 

Overall, the dishes have its roots from Guam but have been elevated to a whole other level. 

Make sure to make a reservation. The space is cozy and it may be difficult to accommodate walk-ins.  We sat right in front of the prep area and were amazed at how they make the small space work. 

The music definitely reminded me of home. 

Looking forward to next time.
author: Joie G.

description: Tasting menu is exceptionally good. Excellent service. Great overall experience, especially for the price.
author: Globey I.

description:
So much more sophisticated and refined than what I remember from visiting to Guam and micronesia years ago-- From that visit I mostly remember Spam and ramen with hot sauce...

The tasting menu is terrific and the venue and staff is very accommodating... On making a reservation for our party of 6, we were advised that parties larger than 5 had to have the $45 tasting menu.  Who knew our group had so many dietary restrictions?!  Out of our party of 6 we had:  1 gluten-free, 1 vegan (but eggs ok), 1 no meat but chicken & fish ok but allergic to lobster, 1 vegetarian, and only 2 w. no restrictions....  Chef Shawn and the waitstaff, including co-owner Shawn C handled all the varied requirements flawlessly and deliciously! Inventive and interesting mix of tasting plates and flavors for all despite our mix of dining restrictions... Everyone enjoyed the experience!
author: Leslie C.

description:
I grew up on Guam in the 60's and 70's and enjoyed not only the native food, but also the strong influence of Japanese, Filipino and Vietnamese food, not to mention the usual mainstream American dishes.

Guamanian food, by virtue of being a small island and limited indigenous edible local plants, is simple. However, being colonized by the Spanish for over 400 years, that influence pervades the cooking style.

So going to Prebechu, I had expectations of Guamanian or Chamorro, (the indigenous people of the Marianas Islands), the way I knew it. While I must admit that Prebechu's style isn't the most traditional, it certainly paves the way of updating and modernizing the traditional tastes and advances it to gourmet classification. The fresh approach remains true to the original tastes and yet, gives you a sense that something else had been heightened.

- First of all, their presentation is spectacular using Asian style plates with playful variety to match the fare.

- Second, the laid back island hospitality is something you can't duplicate and everyone that works there has roots going back to Guam.

- Third, for those uninitiated with Guam food, you wouldn't have a  point of reference to compare, but for one who does know, it is an exalted version of the ubiquitous fiesta food.

It's a tad pricey if you ask me, but it's a hell of a lot cheaper than the $1800 plane ticket to Guam to taste the unique dishes of the western Pacific islands.

Please support these folks for they've added another dimension to the gastronomic choices of cultural diversity in San Francisco. Give it a try and for one meal, get transported to the U.S. Territory of Guam, Where America's Day Begins.
author: Arvey S.

description:
San Francisco needs more restaurants like Prubechu. 

Start with dishes that are authentic to the cuisine or the culture. Make the food accessible without betraying its culinary roots. Throw out pretentious trappings and attitudes. Present everything with genuine service and reasonable prices. Don't leave patrons hungry. 

Prubechu accomplished all of the above. I highly recommend a visit.
author: Keith K.

description: Food is solid, and definitely worth the trip. Support local! Si Yu' us ma asi to the staff, it's definitely a little something to remind us of home in the Oakland/Bay area.
author: Steven R.

description: Absolutely fabulous! One of the best prix fixe menus we have had in SF. The food was clever, delicious, beautifully presented. Everyone working there was beyond lovely, and made us feel that we were at home during our meal. We feel so lucky to have found this incredible restaurant.
author: Jessi H.

description: This place rocked. Off the beaten path and cute inside, the food was DELICIOUS and DIFFERENT. The owner/waiter was incredibly accommodating to my Paleo-esque ways. I really enjoyed it a ton. A+.
author: Andrew K.

description: Really great food, great friendly service.  Shawn and Tracy are charming, professional and delightful.  The mix of flavors is very different than most of the restaurants you've been to.  I highly recommend it.  One half block from the 24th/Mission BART station, on Mission boulevard.
author: Brian B.

description:
Nutshell Appraisal - High cost, low value establishment operated by well-intentioned but delusional proprietors, this spot, without a major shift toward improvement of customer experience, has absolutely no chance of being in business twelve months from now. Plethora of favorable Yelp reviews by so-called Elites within five days' time suspiciously points to platform gaming that smells of pay to play. 

As a fairly adventurous diner who lives in the neighborhood, I thought I would give Prubechu a try. As the server rattled off tropical and Spanish influences, cuisines of the Philippines and Malaysia came to mind. Alas, the memorable and distinguishable ingredients and flavors that define these cultures' gastronomical identities and make them so appealing are not exhibited here.

Because my dining experience was so far removed from the stellar reviews consistently detailed by the first batch of Yelp reviews, I felt compelled to correct the record here.

The first thing you notice upon locating the property is that they've gone for the wink-nod move of retaining the badly-drawn marquee of the former downscale eatery that it has replaced. This is something of a gamble in that it sets the diner up for an expectation that the place is going to make up for this affront and seeming inattention to detail by wowing us with the dining experience itself. The expectation that you're about to bag yet another filling and cheap ethnic eats spot is looming large as you walk south down the still ungentrified block of the Mission shared with BART and McDonalds. A near-certainty reinforced once again upon actually finding the front door and seeing the interior's lack of décor or thought to table settings.

The first major shock, however, comes when the server steers you toward the signature prix fixe menu, offered at $40. Now, there's some considerable risk involved in diving into such a sizable investment with an unknown proprietor delivering relatively obscure cuisine. Even in high-cost San Francisco, $40 can still go a long way. Take the high-end, white gloved Basque-cuisine Piperade that offers impeccable prix fixe menus for under $40 on the edge of the financial district. 

At this price point one expects a minimum quality of service. And as someone who spent a bit of time in the industry, I've always been a bit sensitive to lazy server moves such as auctioning off entrees when the dishes are presented to the table. When this happens with a party of just two, however, it's rather unforgivable as the server is clearly playing entrée roulette. There were similarly awkward gaffs that cumulatively made for an unacceptable level of service.

The $8 bowl of potato soup was quite good. As was the $2 PBR we paired it with (declining not to risk the $12 glass of house red or white on offer). My best advice is to avoid coming too hungry or with anyone who's picky about dining out, and to stick to these two menu items. My $14 entrée was smallish and had a bit of a "what the cupboard has" sensibility to it. Rather bland, it consisted of spaghetti topped by ground beef a la stroganoff with a sauce that appeared to be cream of mushroom soup and coconut milk along with diced asparagus added for good measure. Overall, we left hungry, poorer and wondering WTF, as we ambled up the way to backfill our still empty stomachs with empanadas and mezcal.
author: JayBee L.

description: Delicious, informed, and a great experience. I brought my father here and to be totally honest he was a little hesitant. However we went in and were treated to an exceptional meal. I had the chefs tasting menu for $55, and it was delicious. Each dish came out beautifully presented with some history on the Guam dish and why it is like that. The service was great, our waiter was friendly, attentive, and knowledgeable.
author: monica t.

description: 5 course tasting menu was delicious! Everything was bought fresh this morning from the market. Excellent, attentive service and warm, cozy ambience. I found the portions of each dish to be generous and was very full by the end of the meal. I will definitely be back. Great food with dynamic flavors!
author: Jordan Q.

description:
The service was impeccable.  We wanted for nothing.  Also, I mentioned that I was coled (because I'm wimpy and I get cold easily) and the manager told me he would close it for me, but would have to re-open in from time to time to keep the kitchen from getting too stuffy (this place is small.  He remembered to open and close the door a couple of times during the course of our meal, so I was really impressed with his thoughtfulness.

Also, this was my first experience with Chamorro food and it was really, really good.  We had chicken keleguan and shrimp keleguan, both of which were really light a fresh.  The tortilla thing underneath gave a really nice chewy contrast to the tender topping.  We had the pork with red rice and that red rice was insane.  So flavorful and smoky!  And we also had the empanadas which were light and super crispy and so tasty I didn't care that I scalded my mouth. 

I would LOVE to make it back to this place the next time I'm in SF.  Maybe I'll even make a special trip up there just for the food here.
author: Christina Q.

description:
Send your taste buds on a trip to Guam with the prix fixe at Prubechu.  Although every course was tasty and interesting there were definitely favorites.  Since the menu is seasonal it might be a tease to call out the greatest hits but the the asparagus appetizer, the smelt escabeche, the rice porridge and the dessert course of coconut ice cream, shortbread, and sweet mochi like bite sprinkled with sea salt were "please sir, I want some more" tasty. 

The service was warm and what stood out was how knowledgeable the servers were about each dish including the ingredients and technique, cultural context, and the chef's intent.  Ideally this should always be the case but so often it's disappointingly or frustratingly not the case.  

Enjoy Pebechu for the delicious food and the warm service.  If you are looking for a restaurant with elegant décor and a well-curated Pandora station you might want to go elsewhere.
author: MJ C.

description:
Chamorro cuisine in the city?! It's about time!

A friend of mine had informed me that a new Chamorro restaurant was opening up in the Mission and at first, I thought he was totally kidding, but it turns out that he was absolutely right! 

Prubechu is a hidden little gem that does an amazing job of taking on traditional flavors and ingredients and creating a fresh, fun spin-off of classic Chamorro staples. Being part Chamorro myself, I, like many others swear that my (insert name of "famed cook" in the family here) makes the best chicken kelaguen, red rice, shrimp patties, etc, etc. But I must commend Shawn and Shawn for their thoughtfulness in creating such a simple, yet very tasty and satisfying menu. 

I was originally going to go with a few a la carte items, but ultimately chose to do the 5-course chef's tasting menu, which changes daily. Each course that came out was beautifully plated and explained to us in detail from both Shawn's. I truly cannot decide which dish was my favorite amongst them because everything was delicious in it's own way. Maybe it was the fabulous opening oyster with the kiwi mignonette.. or the slow cooked asparagus with the quail egg on top.. or the coconut milk monkfish kadu.. I can't decide; everything was amazing! 

They also offer a nice little selection of beer and wine (including the hipster classic PBR), accepts credit cards via square and even takes reservations. Quick tip: I inquired about lunch service in the near future and they're currently working on getting more staff on hand to make lunch offerings a reality.. chicken kelaguen tacos, maybe?! 

If you've ever wanted to dabble into Chamorro food, I recommend giving Prubechu a try the next time you're galavanting around the Mission. I'm super stoked that the city FINALLY has some authentic guamanian food on the grid and I wish these guys nothing but the best success! I'll be back very very soon... like tomorrow night.
author: Cara C.

description:
Buen prubechu!

I've never been to Guam.  As we approached Prebechu, I'm wondering, hmm, fish? breadfruit? taro? pork? tropical fruit?   Forget any preconceptions... Prubechu is an unexpected treat for the uninitiated!

The prix fixe tasting menu is an all-savory tour of the Island's food.  Our next table guest Norma was Guamanian and she said she cooks most of the dishes at home.  Legit!

The prix fixe has been really well reviewed so no taste-by-taste here.   Ingredient quality - super high.  Preparation - everything to-order and perfectly presented.  Flavor profile is a patois a bit like the Chamorro language - part Pacific, part Spanish.  Coconut in a variety of presentations and toastednesses complements pork, chicken, beef, corn, rice, noodles, mung beans, snap peas, carrots... a long list.  A different take on soy - YUM.  

The shrimp cake was deconstructed from fried to souffle... I would really like to get a chance to try both approaches side-by-side.  I would really also like to be able to take home a pint of Prebechu's coconut vanilla ice cream.  About as close to heaven as you can get this side of the bright light.  

Don't forget to ask for the hot pepper sauce (if you can handle it!).  From a Guamanian pepper, it is one of the purest hot complements I've ever tasted.  I would like to have it in my kitchen!

Definitely will go back. Looking forward to trying Guam classic tinaktak.  Warm, friendly, satisfying.  Prebechu deserves a place on your "surprise-me" list.
author: Bob K.

description:
Price: average
Food: delicious, great for culturally curious foodies
Presentation: beautiful
Great for a laid back, BYOB date night or fun dinner with friends.

What a wonderful experience all around! The decor is very reminiscent of authentic island laid-back style, totally unassuming in a way that makes you feel like you've found the local hot spot on the island. The service was great, with beautiful presentation and description of each item being placed, understanding that most visitors know nothing of Guam or its cuisine. Its also currently BYOB which is almost impossible to find with this quality of food. Onto the food...

I came with 4 large hungry men and they all ordered the set menu for $40. It looked like too much food for me so I ordered the kelaguen. Each dish was unreal, and the men had trouble finishing all their food because it honestly is a lot of food for $40. I'm used to NYC set menus that tend to leave you hungry and curious as to whether you're just fatter and hungrier than the normal crowd. Not the case here. My kelaguen was delicious, a fairly healthy choice of minced chicken flavored with coconut and island spices, supposedly a very traditional Guamanian dish. I appreciate their great efforts in making a cuisine that most people are completely unfamiliar with and from a fairly laid back island culture into a series of beautifully and professionally presented small plates. Its no small feat to turn home-style island cooking into an elegant affair.

I'd definitely recommend this place, particularly to people who are curious about other cultures and enjoy learning about different cultures via food. I'll definitely be coming back and bringing the whole family. I wish the owners much success! They've clearly worked very hard to bring their dreams to fruition in this cozy spot and I hope they're here to stay!
author: Elena F.

description: I was with a group of lovey ladies who just had an excellent tasting menu dinner at Prubechu! Wonderful atmosphere, delicious, creative and artistic food. It was so fun to watch the chefs and interact with them - telling stories and history of Guam. It was easy to make reservations and the chefs where more than happy to adjust to a few gluten free/dairy free requests. I would highly recommend this restaurant - marvelous experience!
author: Chelsea Q.

description:
When I read the recent review of this restaurant, I knew immediately I had to try it. I went with a friend and my 17 year old son.  We ordered nearly everything on the menu.  Without exception, everything was exceptional. The presentations were beautiful. Clearly a lot of work went into everything. The flavors were unique yet not strange. In fact, some were so extraordinary, I had to shut my eyes to all else around me so I could really enjoy them. 

The potato soup was simply to die for. Don't miss it. The shrimp keleguen...I could have eaten twice as many. The portions were generous yet I ate enough to share with one other person.

What heightened the experience was meeting both owners, hearing their stories about Guam, and feeling the pride they have for their country. We could have talked for hours. Their love for food, creative adaptations of traditional dishes, and pure enjoyment of making sure we knew what we were eating and how everything was prepared turned what we thought would be a "quick bite to eat" into a 2 hour dining experience. 

Even my teenage son was interested in how things were made and came home to tell several friends and family about it.

Needless to say, the service was like being in someone's home. Both Shawns were exceptionally gracious and made us feel totally special. The place is adorable, has a very warm feeling and quickly transports you away from the local street color. 

This place will now be on my favorites list, and when we have a large family gathering at the end of the month, we are going to have lunch here.  It is simply unforgettable.
author: Marla Z.

description:
This place is fusion type of chamorro food. Now if your from Guam fusion is it usual but I get what this place is trying to put out. It's a mix of different islands but on an upscale level. They are located on the mission the place is like an old sushi place so to big inside. Customer service was ok. The food can't be explained but flavor was bursting & different.

Being chamorro I can relate to some of the flavors but some are quit different that really don't need adjusting but tasted good. I think I just have to get use to fusion but completely not traditional so don't expect it if your coming here.
author: Mark T.

description:
A creative gourmet twist on traditional Chamorro food.  Either ala carte entrees or the tasting menu will have your taste buds dancing.  Ate here with my gf and good friend who is a foodie and after tasting each dish, she wanted to hurt the chef cuz it was so dam good. LOL
Come here if you want to experience unique gourmet Chamorro food!
author: Marlon L.

description: I'm Chamorro and I wouldn't recommend this place. Food had no flavor, dry meat and no taste with red rice.  Not my island experience.
author: Shelly W.

description:
Had a great time here with a few friends on a sat night.  We went with the tasting menu and we're definitely educated on some new flavor combinations and dishes from Guam.  This is definitely a hidden gem at a reasonable price point (for now at least) that brings something fresh to this strip of mission.  

We will definitely be back to try some other dishes.  One note is that you better like coconut since it's in each dish in some form or another pretty much.
author: Chris T.

description: Newish when I went a month or so ago - incredible food and service, very fair prices and a friendly crowd too! Highly recommended, and will return soon! Guam rules!
author: Jeff K.

description: Good but not great especially considering the price. The staff is extremely nice but a bit slow. The food was all Spanish inspired but didn't execute that well. We especially didn't like the red rice dish or the ceviches. Would recommend the desserts though, especially the ice cream
author: Lisa B.

description:
We went for the tasting menu and got the following: 

1) Miyagi with the kiwi was really good. Didn't know they would complement each other so well. The oyster was very fresh too. 

2) Egg with avocado and carmaelized soy - egg had a creamy center. It needed more of that avocado mousse. Also, after a while it started to taste like a '1000 yr old egg'. I still enjoyed it a lot.

3) Chicken keleguan - This was really good. It tasted like a very healthy chicken salad with some coconut dressing. 

4) Shrimp Patty - like everyone said, texture is more souffle than an actual patty. But i liked it. The corn mixed inside made it sweet. 

5) Chalakilis - very flavorful porridge, I got some big pieces of pork belly. So by this time I'm pretty full. Pork belly was really good, it was hot, crispy, and fatty. But not so much that I felt greasy afterwards. Then there was the quail egg, I don't know how they did it, but the yolk was still runny when I popped it in my mouth. 

6) Kadu - there was rice, some clear noodles, sprouts, potatoes, carrots, and short ribs. Then they top it over some soup and you can mix it with the vinegar they give you. It was delicious! It reminded me of korean kalbi soup. 

7) Homemade ice cream - Ice cream had a very natural coconut flavor. This was complemented with the cookie crumble and a torched meringue. Everything went very well together. 

Overall, food was good. I enjoyed the whole experience and each bite, but I don't think it's enough to make me dream about it. Also, I walked out of the place with a full belly but I still don't know what Guam food is. I felt like I had a fusion of Mediterranean, Chinese, Vietnamese, and Korean. I like all 4, so i'm overruling the technical aspects in this review.
author: Irene C.

description: Passionated owners come together and create food with pride and style. I wish more restaurants in SF had the same ethics. Pricy but you pay for a flawless experience
author: Jonathan F.

description: Great service, excellent food. Incredible value for the money. Most restaurants of this quality cost WAY more.
author: Matthew M.

description: Great spot and great attentive service. We had the chef's tasting menu and I highly recommend it. Like many reviewers I had no idea what to expect but I saw the good reviews and thought it would be a great place to try out.  $45 was the price for the Chef's Tasting menu per person.  Look forward to returning sometime in the future.
author: Rod M.

description: We had a delicious meal!  5 courses but really 7 with amuse bouche and dessert.  We were stuffed and loved 6/7 dishes!  The short rib was the best I've ever had, amazing soup, and really fresh, interesting flavors.  It was a hot night so we were a bit warm, but no real complains.
author: EK G.

description: The food was ok, but I literally saw a rat / mouse scurry under my dining partner's legs when I ate here on a weekday night. Definitely not coming back because of that.
author: Andy A.

description:
After seeing such stellar reviews, I was strikingly underwhelmed by this experience. The emphasis seems to be highly on things that are considered excellent in Guam, without, in my opinion, much consideration for overall value or flavor.

Tried the ceviche, beer, wine, fermented coconut juice, red rice (their "best seller"- really? Rice?), and the market fish. Ceviche was nice but mild- relatively more bland than the average Latin ceviche, and less citrus-forward. The rice was entirely unremarkable. Perhaps the side portion is prepared differently than the entree (though we asked about this before ordering, and were told it is not), but it had hardly anything in it that wasn't... rice. The fish was the part of the meal that was really frustrating. For $38 (more than 1.5x the price of the next most expensive menu item, price not listed), we were served a small (~10oz bone in & head on), steamed reef fish. It was fine, but far too bland for my taste. We left feeling entirely unfulfillled to get ice cream down the street.

Overall, this would perhaps be a very fine restaurant in Guam... but I would encourage prospective diners to consider that Guam is a tiny island in the deep Pacific, and not known for its cuisine. At San Francisco prices, you can do much, much better on this side of the ocean.
author: Jesse O.

description: I've been wanting to try Prubechu since I read about it and when we made it to the Bay Area this weekend, we no doubtedly had to come try it out!  It's not your typical Chamorro BBQ joint. This is the kind of place that foodies like.  Guam dishes presented in a culinary style like no other.   Shawn Camacho, Shawn Naputi and their island boys took us on a unique culinary journey with an interesting twist on our home grown dishes we already loved.  Chorizos español, kelaguen, shrimp patty, eggplant, chalikis, kadu, apigigi.  We have to come back next time we are in town.  Congrats to our local boys doing it island style their way!
author: Michele M.

description: Had such a great dinner! Probably one of the best in San Francisco. These guys not only cook with great flavor but plate with such great fineness! Service was spot on too! I recommend the chefs tasting menu for sure!
author: Alicia S.

description: Have the tasting menu. I've dined here at least 7 or 8 times, and love it. The food here is a bit different from the usual "modern American" fare since it is heavily influenced with Guamanian ingredients and flavors, which makes it interesting and in many ways more complex. A plus, is the warmth and friendliness of chef Shawn and his business partner Shawn. They really make you feel welcome and appreciated. Awesome.
author: Connie H.

description:
this is the taste of home elevated to foodie status. chamorros, don't expect your grandma's tinaktak or an l&l style bbq plate. this is indeed elevated island cuisine and it couldn't be better. i never thought i'd be able to enjoy red wine with chamorro food in the mission. great place and great people.

p.s. the manha ice cream is the stuff dreams are made of. move over bi-rite.
author: Jackie B.

description:
My wife and two sons thoroughly enjoyed our meal at Prubechu.  We all had the tasting menu and were completely blown away from the presentation to the flavors...all done incredibly well. Our favorites (if we had to choose, because they were all so good) were the chalakilis (a rice porridge dish), kelaguen (grated coconut and chicken) and kadun katne (beef short ribs soup)...all dishes staying true to Chamorro roots with a slight slash of contemporary flair.

The Shawn's (the two owners, one a host and the other the chef) are very gracious and welcoming...we wish them the best of luck and can't wait to come back!
author: Island B.

description:
What a fun dining experience! Went here the other night with a group of 4, and we all ordered the chef tasting menu, which as others have mentioned, is a really fantastic deal. We appreciated that they asked about food allergies/dietary restrictions (we didn't) when we ordered. I always take that as a sign that a chef is creative and flexible, and the staff is interested in pleasing every customer from the beginning.

Each course was excellent and beautifully prepared. I wish I had written down a description of each item, but overall it was a wonderful mix of flavor, texture, spice, smoke, seafood, pork, and fresh produce. Each course was unique and provided a new flavor--no filler courses here! The candied coconut ice cream was a perfect dessert for the 90-degree weather that day. One of the highlights of our experience was seeing the passion that the chef, co-owner, and servers had for the food and cuisine. They went into detail about history, sources, and cooking methods for each dish, answered all of our questions with enthusiasm, and were happy to share their story and backgrounds. It's so inspiring to see good, talented people pursue their dream, and do it well.  Anyone looking for a unique, delicious dining experience needs to get to Prubechu, stat.
author: Alison S.

description: I love Prubechu! We had the tasting menu twice and both times the food was phenomenal! The dining experience is very interesting - the food is Guamanian, all prepared by Guamanians on hot plates! That's right, hot plates! There is no stove! Yet, somehow, they manage to cook each dish perfectly! I'm impressed!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I went because I've never tried food from Guam and for the ridiculous high reviews.  I'm glad I didn't cancel because between the making the reservation and the res date,  (and always the pessimist )I'd convinced myself those reviews were fake.   Glad to say that it was a enjoyable experience.

As part of group of 8, we had to participate in the tasting menu.

The deep fried 6 min egg wowed everyone.  If you've read the egg description it seems like they started at 8 min eggs and perfected this at 6 mins.  Texture and flavor was really good. This item is the one thing that everyone at the table would return for.

My personal favorite was the house cured/smoked bacon w/ deep fried maitakes which tasted like meat ,which was awesome. Some in the group didn't like the dryness but I loved it.

Braised oxtails -winner.

There was a leaf wrapped fish "sausage" thingy in coconut milk sauce that was kinda bland since I didn't use spicy sauce on the side.   It was too spicy for me to try twice. My Filipino  friend liked this dish. 

Also a deep fried fish dish which was ok.  
 
We received complimentary ice cream and amuse buche oyster.  Over all food was nicely presented (if you care about that kind of detail) and tasty and service was good so I'll return.
author: chio s.

description: Try the tasting menu. Just do it, it's delicious. A little pricey, but so damn good. I had the tasting menu around the time they first opened (March I think), which was delicious. Had it again just the other night and it was almost entirely different yet still damn delicious. And they have dishes in the trading menu that you can't get a la carte.
author: Mark S.

description: Got the tasting menu and I think it's a steal! It's a small, relatively okay looking place but the service and the food are outstanding. The waitstaff explained each course, and were very attentive to our needs. The food was plated beautifully, and it tasted as good as it looked. My favorites are the oyster (like butter), egg course (balanced taste), and the coconut ice cream dessert.
author: Rae C.

description:
Truly thoughtful dishes, that will surprise and satisfy you!

Came here on a date night for the tasting menu last night and it's such an delightful experience. Great service, decent ambiance, and the quality/presentation of the food is on the same level as to State Bird and Provisions.

The highlights were Chalakilis (juicy crispy and savory pork belly almost made me cry) and oxtail soup (wholesome, taste like home).
author: Jessica Z.

description:
I had the vegetarian dish with side of rice and wine. Absolutely loved my meal!! The texture of veggies were crisp and lively- just right.  The best part of the meal is that the flavor was perfect.  I hail from Asia and I find that almost all Asian food in this city tries too hard by over-salting, over-spicing... Not so at Prubechu, flavors are very well balanced! I will definitely come back to try other items.
Oh, and the house red was good!
author: S H.

description:
It's like taking a vacation without leaving the City. The tasting menu was absolutely amazing. An explanation of every plate, from ingredients used to how may have been served in Guam. Service was incredibly friendly and personable. We felt more like we were at a friend's home than a restaurant. 

Go there to experience the food, the culture and to support people who are adding something really special to San Francisco's food scene.
author: Bridget M.

description: these guys are dedicated to their craft. they try to bring awesome, home cook meals to another level and succeed. the chefs menu is fantastic and worth the money. i had so many different things ive never tried, all which were phenomenal.
author: Jonathan Q.

description: The food and the staff are first class. Highlights: pork belly & fried egg, farmers market salad, corn and coconut soup, Viognier.
author: Susan J.

description:
Food presentation was delicious and the food was yummy!
Service was wonderful!
Great place to meet up with family and friends from Guam...
author: Catherine R.

description: I Ordered the Chef's Choice Tasting Menu (5 tasty dishes specially prepared by the chefs) & everything was fresh, delicious with spectacular flavors with a Chamorro base! I can't remember all the fresh ingredients in each of the dishes but they were all outstanding! The service was excellent, too!  I'll be going back in September when I'm back in San Francisco!
author: Elaine B.

description: We finally get to make it to this place then for some reason the restaurant is closed! Frustrating because I'm in crutches; waking there after finally parking only to find out this place is closed! On a Saturday night! No sign or anything, lights off, even after calling to make reservations! Yelp says it's open, all the other sites say it's open. Ugh! The least they an do is update their Facebook page!
author: Shirlene M.

description: This place was totally unexpectedly amazing. It's got the vibe of a fun diner, totally casual, with a nice energy, but the food that came out of that kitchen was nothing short of spectacular. I think I gasped every time a dish came out! I like to consider myself fairly well versed in world cuisine, but Chamorro cuisine from Guam is unlike anything I'd ever tasted before. Everything hit the right note, with the right amount of sweet, salty, sour, and textural contrast, not to mention the food was beautifully presented. The service was great, Shawn was super nice and we enjoyed some awesome craft beer and a great Riesling with our meal. The tasting menu was seriously good value too, I've never had a $40 tasting menu that was even close to that good. I've already been back and will be back a lot more!
author: Caroline C.

description:
Chamorro food with an upscale twist. 

I was very satisfied with the food at Prubechu. The chef knows how to take classic Chamorro dishes and infuse them with a culinary touch, while staying true to the heart and soul of the dish. There were 4 of us so we ordered one (sometimes two) of everything and ate it family style. My favorites were the Golai Hagan Suni, Tinaktak and red rice/pork. Request the donne dinanche (housemade pepper paste) to add a spicy kick to any of the dishes, and don't pass up the coconut candy ice cream for dessert - soooo good.

Few critiques: They should offer a full pint glass when you order a beer versus a mini mason jar. Chicken keleguen could have used a splash more lemon juice. 

Other than that - the food was delicious, service was excellent, and I can't wait to go back.
author: Brooks H.

description: Not the food your grandma makes, but something that will definitely remind you of it. Food is beautifully presented and owners are welcoming. If you haven't had food from Guam, do it, and do it here. See Joie G's review for a more detailed review. I was part of her large party. They are very flexible about food interlorances and allergies so just let them know. We did the tasting menu. Meal has been awhile but I remember enjoying my dishes. Coconut soups, achote grits, makerel, and the dessert of pigigy (sticky coconut rice) with ice cream is what sticks out in my head the most! One cool thing that my brother ordered that sounded interesting was their homemade pasta with tinaktak (coconut milk, vegetables, and meat). I had no more room left to try it, but that was just to give you an example of what they are trying to do with Chamorro (Guamanian) food.
author: Hazel F.

description: Can't say enough good things about this place.. We eat out at all the Bay Area hotspots and have to say this ranks right up at the top !
author: Jorinne J.

description: I had never tried Guamese(?) food before and it really blew my mind when I least expected it. We ordered the Chef's Tasting Menu for $55 and it was 7 courses of amazing food. My favorite was the rice porridge with a 6 minute egg with truffle on top. We ordered Mt. Beautiful wine that was really smooth and went well with all the food. Service was great and it was nice to talk to the owner. A real gem in the heart of the Mission.
author: Selen U.

description: Wtf. It's Saturday night and this place closed. Dragged my 2 toddlers and sister in law on crutches and the place is closed. I think it closed down.
author: Fe C.

description:
Go now before Mission foodies discover Prubechu! 

I expected various varieties of spam - or at least that's what I heard about food in Guam, instead I got an innovative, delicious and gourmet dinner for a portion of the price that dishes of this caliber would be priced at other establishments.

We had the 5 course savory tasting menu and added flat bread and pickles. At the end of the meal the chef snuck in dessert too. Food was a gourmet journey, what a treat!
author: Yana M.

description: This has got to be the newest, must-try restaurant in SF! Hurry before reservations become impossible to get! Their basic menu is the tasting menu with various add-ons. It was absolutely delicious with every bite, filling, and satisfying. I had never tried Guamanian food... and thank God I love coconut because it was in almost every dish! I thought it was cute that they serve many different types of beer, including Pabst (for $2!). The service and ambiance is genuine and no-frills. I felt like I was being served by a bunch of my close friends with their non-stuffy, friendly, caring attitude.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Great customer service! You can best describe their menu as bomb comfort food. It's unique food genre and Chamorro culture gives the best hospitality I've experienced in San Francisco! Highly recommend this spot!!
author: Tony P.

description: Ordered the tasting menu.  1 amuse Bouche 4 courses and 1 delicate dessert. All really really delicious. The food was great. Our server was lovely and kind and it felt like a comfortable down home type of place.
author: Jessica M.

description: MOUTH-GASIM awaits you -just go! hella bomb food with a crew that is as sweet as the coconut henny IceCream they make! Authentic food from Americas best kept secret, Guam! I personally love the chicken ceviche sprinkled with coconut and spicy goodness! Reggae beats and delicious treats you can't go wrong! Gracias for my happy belly!
author: Alexa T.

description: Love this place. I moved to SF from Guam and this place makes me feel like I'm at home. It's a more sophisticated take on Chamorro food, but the red rice is just like I remember. Everyone I came with loved their dishes, too.
author: Ryan S.

description: this is one of the mission's true gems. a down to earth, local place with fantastic food and great value. beautiful atmosphere without mission attitude, small and intimate but still fun & lively.
author: steve r.

description: Nothing special. The pasta dish didn't have any flavor and wasn't even properly seasoned. The overpriced red rice dish is just average tasting pork belly. The service was good.
author: Serguei B.

description: We had the tasting menu last night and it was totally unexpected in a great way. We weren't expecting much when we walked into the restaurant. The place looked tidy but very straightforward. You would probably never remember the look of the place but you will totally remember the food. We had 5 courses and all of them had really interesting flavors and ingredients. There was a crusted fried egg with asparagus, a rice porridge like dish with mushrooms and sardines, and a great braised short rib in broth. We would definitely come back!
author: Q L.

description:
Came here based on a recommendation from someone who grew up in Guam. What is Guamanian food?? I'm always down to try new things, and seeing as how this is the first and only Guamanian restaurant I've heard of, I was intrigued. For groups of 5 or more, everyone has to be on board for the tasting menu. $45 gets you five courses, not including the amuse bouche and dessert. Fortunately, they allowed my friend to opt out of the tasting menu, and to just order a la carte because of her strong aversion to coconut (90% of their dishes have coconut). We didn't know what we were getting until each course came out because they didn't have a printed menu of the tasting menu. With the exception of one course (ground up chicken in banana leaf), we all thoroughly enjoyed the food! It was very flavorful and while coconut was in everything, it wasn't overwhelming and all that pronounced in some dishes (and I only like coconut in some foods). 

Overall, the service was good. However, it did take a really long time for the dessert course, around 30-40 minutes. When they forgot to sub my oxtail for fish, our server Shawn apologized and comped our bottle of wine. He really didn't have to do that, but we definitely appreciated it :) So even after eating Guamanian/Chamorro food, my friends and I still can't clearly define what it is. Some words that were thrown out to describe it: Latin, Asian, island, Spanish, Filipino, spam, coconut, and lastly, delicious!!
author: Kat E.

description:
I didn't even know Guamanian food was a thing, but now I do.   And I like it.  Very unique flavors and plates (all well prepared).

Staff was really friendly and helpful.  I'll be returning.
author: Joe H.

description: My wife and I were in San Francisco from Toronto for the weekend and wanted to eat somewhere interesting, and Prubechu certainly fit that bill. We highly recommend the tasting menu for first timer's like ourselves. Both of us agreed that this was one of the best meals we've had together. The flavors were so unique and so artfully put together. We really appreciated the attention to detail and the mindfulness of the servers. The shaved coconut salted ice cream desert that we ordered was to die for! This restaurant makes us want to visit Guam ourselves, it was that good.
author: Nadeem M.

description: This place is awesome. The food is great and everyone is really friendly. Went with the tasting menu and it was an amazing  course dinner. Flavors are really unique and a great experience.
author: Nehal M.

description: A real find. Not only is the food delicious, the people who run the place do everything to make you feel welcome and well-fed. Head chef Sean (sp?) used to cook at Incanto and his serious cooking chops show. Meanwhile, everyone at the restaurant feels like family. Hope they last a good long time.
author: Alice W.

description:
We were served the tasting menu and it definitely was a memorable experience! Food was exquisite both in terms of taste and presentation without being pretentious. Staff was genuinely warm and knowledgeable about their dishes. We saw one of the chefs inventing a dish on the spot, probably for a dietary restriction.

Congratulations on a job well done!
author: Simona N.

description: We just had an outstanding dinner at Prebechu! Go for the tasting menu and you will get plate after plate of AMAZING food brought to your table. The pacing was perfect as were the portions. The servers were friendly, knowledgable and clearly passionate about the food. Such a great find!
author: E B.

description: inventive recipes and fantastic service. a bit pricy but only way to survive mission gentrification...it's a cycle, no one is immune...keep up the good work!
author: Xiu L.

description: I am obsessed with this place. Every dish is both beautifully prepared and presented, the food is flavorful and filling but not heavy, and every time I get the tasting menu there is something new I have never tried. Also, the chefs are awesome and friendly. Go here!!
author: Zoelle E.

description: Delicious and unique dining experience! We each ordered the tasting menu and were delighted with every course. We will definitely be back!
author: Lauren D.

description: Wow, creative dishes, superb taste, excellent presentation, and friendly staff. One of my top 10 food experiences in SF!
author: Angela L.

description:
A friend who knows his stuff picked this place and it kind of blew our minds. It's a nondescript and fairly plain room in an otherwise great location, but the service and food was full of enthusiasm and authenticity and was one of the better meals I've had this year. First off a $45 7 course tasting menu is almost ludicrously cheap for this quality - it'd be a great deal at double the price.

As for the meal, it started off with an oyster amuse bouche - pretty standard but with the coconut vinegar it had a hint of Southeast Asia that set the tone for the rest of the night. Following was a cold smoked potato soup with more coconut coming through the creamy base. Next up was a Guamanian ceviche with some house made spicy chips and an oily ash base that grounded (literally!) the flavours. After that we had a house made chicken sausage that usually comes stuffed inside a chicken neck but for North American tastes was altered to be stuffed inside a banana leaf. Paired with a house made sriracha like sauce that gave the lightly seasoned protein bit of bite and we really started to realize this was going to be an unexpectedly memorable dinner. The fifth course was easily my favorite; a panko breaded soft boiled egg resting on top of house made "spam". Vaguely reminiscent of Wyly Dufresnes famous deconstructed eggs Benedict it was the simplest but tastiest dish of the night. But not by much...the penultimate course was a braised short rib on top of glass noodles surprisingly finished with a light broth. At this point I need to mention our server (who may also have been one of the co-owners). His dish descriptions were filled with phrases like "my grandma's recipe" and "back home we eat it like this", etc. It's clear these kids are cooking and running the front of house with a ton of passion and genuine love for Guamanian food. But it ain't over yet! Dessert was a coconut ice cream with some kind of fired tapioca that turned it into almost a biscuit or shortbread. Rad. 

All in all a stellar meal. Probechu - get some before it blows up!
author: Andy M.

description: Just awesome.  Get the tasting menu.  Accept the wine recommendations.  Go, now!   Visiting SF from Boston, wildly impressed.   You'll be glad you went.
author: Eric Z.

description: Quite the fresh new Mission addition. First time here and  our party was surprised beyond belief. It's too good to be true Prubechu. Coming back for the atmosphere, innovative dishes and generous peeps. I did have a "Barcelona" moment before entering. Deja vu.
author: DS K.

description: Last night was our first time at Prubechu. The food was amazing, service was personal and made you feel like a guest in their home. Definitely try the chefs menu and let their culinary talent lead the way.
author: Paula W.

description: As a Chamorro and SF native, I've been waiting for someone to serve up our culture with pride and love, and now it's here.  Prubechu takes authentic, family recipes to the next level by putting their own gourmet, palate exploding spin on them.  The ideas are amazing, the ingredients fresh, staff truly Island welcoming(Prubechu) and the result is a dining experience to be remembered.  The Shawn's have set the bar on the new "go to" restaurant and if you're looking to explore something completely unexpected and rare...my friend, you've found it.  Run run run down to 24th and Mission, grab a seat and be prepared to be amazed.  This is the city's newest gem.  All of your senses will be taken to new and unexpected heights.  Si yu'us ma'ase Prubechu!
author: Michael M.

description: Wow. Huge flavors. Tasting menu is a must, and the ice cream will change your life. Service impeccable also. 8/10 will come back.
author: Jarrett S.

description: Food was delicious and really unique... The owners are wonderful with true passion for their work...
author: Bill R.

description: Awesome food, the chefs tasting menu was delicious and the variety is amazing. I've never had Guamanian good before but this place taught me all about it and then I lived everything! Would totally go back! Keep it up! Thanks for your hospitality!
author: Ashley B.

description:
I'm not from Guam, nor have I ever been there. But my ex is Chamorro and a lot of my friends are from Guam, so I've eaten homemade Chamorro on a number of occasions (i.e. Red Rice, Shrimp Patties, Keleguen, Tinaktak, etc.). No where I have eaten food like this. It's like amped up Guam food taking all the classics and making them exceptional. I love that the place is in the Mission, just a block away from Bart. You need to be aware of the address as the signage is not up yet, but I love that cause it makes it under the radar. I went for a going way dinner on a Wednesday night and we all did the tasting menu, which was amazing and to die for. I loved every single dish, so much so that I lost track of taking pictures and that's pretty bad for me since I'm #AsiansTakingPicturesOfFood. My highlights were the chilled corn soup with deep fried nori, Kadu with carrots and squash, Chicken Keleguen with shredded coconut and the Coconut Candy Ice cream was heaven. I devoured that Coconut ice cream after thinking I could no longer stuff anything else in me. Note that the Chef Tasting Menu changes based upon produce and recipe changes, but that's the best since you can always come back and enjoy another experience. Just sit back and let all these amazing dishes come to you.

Tips:
Order Chef's Tasting Menu ($45 -you will not regret it- very creative and super tasty)
Take the Bart - get off at Mission and 24th (unless you want to fight for parking)
Take notice of the address- no sign up yet
Causal but Intimate scene
author: Jennifer Y.

description: The staff was very friendly, but I wasn't super excited about the food or the price. The chicken keleguen was good but not as good as I was expecting. You also get pretty small portions for the prices. The ambiance was also not great - very loud music.
author: amanda m.

description:
This was an exceptional dining experience.  The food was delicious, the service was extremely attentive, and the attitude of the staff was phenomenal!!!

We had the tasting menu, and it was worth every penny.  5 courses, and all were great!  Several waiters/waitresses served us, and each one gave us a detailed description of the dish and its ingredients, and even some background on the dish!

They take a lot of pride in what they serve, and are more than happy to tell you about the food, its ingredients, and its preparation.

They were all extremely friendly and good natured!

An extra thank you to Tracy, who was our main waitress!  She was awesome!

I will definitely go back.  Highly recommended!!!
author: Elie S.

description: Great job and wonderful tasting menus, friendly and flexible staff. Highly recommended!
author: Athena L.

description: Fantastic meal.  Tasting menu was 5 excellent courses that got increasingly more substantial, with an amuse bouche and dessert to boot.  It's the perfect balance of comfort food and elevated--nothing feels out of place or unnecessary.  The yam fritter and homemade coconut ice cream were the secret stars, but all of the dishes shined.  Can't recommend it enough and couldn't be happier for the Shawns and the new place.
author: Chris J.

description: My wife is Guamanian and her parents are restauranteurs so it takes a lot to impress me- but i was very impressed. The food was absurdly good, the service was personal and the ambiance was relaxed. The pride that the cooks and host have in the island and their food is clearly evident. I'm looking forward to my next meal there.
author: Greg R.

description: An excellent tasting menu of coconut, fish and pork -inflected Chamorro food. Plenty of pickled vegetables, and a fun coconut liquor. Prubechu may be the most careful and detailed food I have ever eaten, at that price point. The server Sean was gracious and attentive. The space could have used a bit more ventilation.
author: Ben G.

description: nothing like it in the city!  Did the tasting menu with a group of 5.  Really creative and flavorful dishes - each course was better than the last.  This place is a huge find. Looking forward to going back again soon!
author: meaghan r.

description: we went with a big group and all did the tasting menu. i thought every dish was good, some were delicious. the two all-stars were the breaded soft boiled egg and the sea salt ice cream. those two dishes were so amazingly unique and tasty and i'd love to have them again, but the price doesn't seem worth it. staff was friendly and informative. the male server was trying to be very cautious of the people with food allergies at our table, yet somehow the other servers kept serving them the exact dishes they weren't supposed to receive. even though they were apologetic about it, it's not something i find acceptable that they made the same mistake for several courses. in general, it was a nice dining experience but i probably won't be rushing back
author: Anjelica C.

description: My fiancée and I had the chefs tasting and supplemented it with the pickles, soup, and salad. What a wonderful meal. Service was also wonderful. Favorite dishes: porridge, oxtail stew and the candied ice cream. A tremendous value.
author: Ish H.

description: Most welcoming and friendly service in SF.  Sean and his staff are great and really make you feel like family.  The Chamorro menu is great and a unique addition to the culinary scene.  Do not miss the coconut ice cream dessert.  I will definitely go back sometime soon for the full tasting menu.
author: Stan B.

description: Awesome tasting menu in a very family atmosphere. If you are not Guamanian you will be made to feel like you are.
author: Derek S.

description:
I was once an ignorant person. I had never had Guam (Guamese? Guamish?)  cuisine before. Now, since this is my ONLY time trying this cuisine, I can't speak to its authenticity or whatever, I just know it is pretty dang tasty. As unusual as this may sound, it felt like a cross between American southern barbeque (just a bit, a lot of smoky flavors) and a more restrained Thai cuisine (a lot of coconut used but less sweet). Oh mama, that's a good combo.

I, like many others, got the prix fixe five course option. It's not extremely filling, but you get to try a lot of different things, and they were all pretty great. My companion and I split that and we also got the red rice plate, which is a big plate of food, in stark contrast to the tasting menu. So, get the prix fixe for variety, order another plate if you want a big hearty meal. 

I should also mention the service, which was uncommonly personable and warm. And for a fairly nice restaurant, it was refreshingly lacking in pretense. Great experience, an underrated restaurant in the Mission that I suspect will become overcrowded sometime in the future.
author: Dustin Y.

description: This restaurant  is not of this planet... the food was beyond amazing and the atmosphere equally impressive.  The kelaguen Uhang(shrimp ceviche) was ridiculous, delicious doesn't even begin to describe how good it was.....I am so impressed by this restaurant and you would be stupid not to eat here
author: Alexander B.

description: The Tasting Menu blew my mind!! Most amazing courses I have had in a long time!! And the coconut ice cream was the best way to end the meal!  Great job guys!
author: Ernie S.

description:
4.5 stars
Top-drawer experience. Went in on 3/20 at about 8:03 pm w/ a pal.  Pal had regular tasting menu - I had the pescetarian tasting menu. Each item was tasty and unique in flavor. The server, Sean, explained each dish in a polite, enthusiastic manner. The pacing between courses was perfect.  We had time to appreciate and savor each concoction that Chef Sean made.  And $40 for a tasting menu in SF - what a deal - just right portions - zippy flavor. Impeccable service - everyone was just super nice and passionate.  Will def go back as Chef Sean uses seasonal ingredients -- will want to see how he mixes things up. Stand-out dishes for me were the amuse buche oyster with a coconut vinegar - the porridge w/anchovy and cauliflower - and the soft boiled egg w/ roe and house-cured salmon. So good - all paired with a smooth Riesling. A very welcome addition to SF.
author: Carson R.

description: Prix fixe was phenomenal. So many diverse flavors and the presentation on every meal was superb.
author: Rick L.

description: absolutely an amazing dining experience.  the ambiance is solid - great music, calm and relaxing service - the entire team is from Guam and the food is authentic.  delicious and fresh.  Highly recommend the chef's tasting menu!
author: Cindy B.

description: Quite the gem. Had the tasting menu and it was delicious. Also extremely affordable for a tasting menu.  The only downside is as the restaurant got busier, our food came out slower.
author: Quang N.

description: This was a disappointment! The food is NOT traditional or authentic Chamorro food? What is Fusion? They don't have that in Guam is it something they made up? Being from Guam , 100 % Guamanian / Chamorita everyone knows we make our food from our grandmas & moms recipes, we cook our food to represent our culture "the CHAMORRO People"so to make this little bit of food when Chamorros are known to have big parties or fiesta this was a disgrace. We had the chef's choice spend over $200 for 2 people that was a rip off! Also never spent that much money & still was hungry & got food right after , we left at Chevys across from the W. I'm not sure how they are making it ? but I wouldn't pay another penny to eat at this place if it was the last thing on earth. The place is small doesn't feel like Guam hospitality more like a Japanese sushi house right on the mission. Not sure where they got their recipes but definitely NOT representing our culture ! The reviews must be by NON-Chamorro customers & friends of owners because there is no way they represent GUAM. What is fusion anyways?
author: Lani A.

description: Food was perfectly flavorful, authentic, and cooked with love. We felt well taken care of by the friendly and warm staff.  Loved the quaint/unpretentious vibe, and enjoyed chatting with the chef in the open kitchen. Such a treat!!
author: Anastasia C.

description: Went here on the recommendation of a friend, and were we glad we did. We ordered the tasting menu and were not disappointed. Food was delicious and well presented. The service was warm and friendly, with each course accompanied by information about the dish and its provenance. Nice, bright place that is not too loud, and has a relaxed, comfortable vibe. Highly recommended!
author: Avinash K.

description: My favorite restaurant in SF! We usually share the tasting menu plus a main. It's all fabulous so you can't go wrong. This Friday there was awesome live music.
author: Laura V.

description: Never been to a Guamanian restaurant. Is Guamanian even a word? Anyhow, Prubechu was a cool experience. I was really looking forward to trying something new. I had the tasting menu and was really impressed. I wish I could remember the names of the dishes, but I predict it won't be long until this cuisine becomes mainstream and we all know the names of dishes from Guam. I had some kind of coconut chicken and a porridge that had quail eggs. They were delicious. Apparently the menu changes every now and then. Great idea! I will have to come back to see what's new in a few weeks.
author: Eduardo M.

description: We've been to Prubechu twice and were blown away both times by the unique and exquisite flavors. We ate vegetarian both times and found the food to be similar to our experience eating Burmese in SF in that the flavors were unexpected, sometimes complex, and unlike any other food we've had the pleasure of stuffing in our faces. Impressive food, Friendly people, Cozy environment. Go Here! Yum!
author: Suki L.

description: A chefs energy flows from his hands and what Shaun Naputi is doing here is a great example of elevating a modest cuisine to refinement without loosing its soul. Course by course my party of six was delighted by the unique yet familiar flavors that reminded us of growing up in Guam, every dish teased our palates and left us excited for the next course. Our 6 course tasting was flawless. Great Job Shaun and Shaun!
author: Riko M.

description:
Had a great meal here!
Thank you Shawn & Shawn for this fantastic new addition to the SF food scene.
author: Agnes B.

description:
What a nice change of pace! The Shawns are super nice and friendly and the food is delicious with enough selection that a vegetarian can eat here easily. Lots of coconut flavor in what I had and it was not really like any other cuisine I've had. Super friendly hosts, too!

Check it out, wish the Shawns the best - hope this place sticks around!
author: Ara S.

description: I must admit, I was a little hesitant when I stepped into this place at 7:30pm (on a Tuesday) and there was only one other couple there. It looked more like a cafe, there was no sign outside, the menu was just a little card with a few items on it. I whipped out my phone to double-check the Yelp reviews and that convinced me to try the place out and overlook the ambiance. And I'm glad I did. So thanks everyone! We got the 5 course tasting menu, which I think actually ended up being 8 courses or so. And everything was perfect! The service was amazing, and the place definitely looked cuter at night with the candlelight. I'm surprised this place isn't busier, but then again, they just opened up a couple months ago! Go check it out while there's no line-up!
author: Salimah J.

description: Absolutely amazing food. A breath of new tastes for the city. The tasting menu is of amazing value. Can't go wrong. They take reservations over email or the phone so just call them up.
author: Diego D.

description: Authentic, enjoyable, and great amazing atmosphere. Very classy but still has a close family vibe to it. We love it and will be back!!!
author: Auna B.

description: Majority of foods I've eaten before tonight are no longer worthy to be on my palette. Coconut ice cream....amazing.
author: Brittany C.

description: Tracy was a wonderful host and added to the experience of eating at Prubechu.  My wife is from the Philippines and I am from Hawaii but this was a very new dining experience for us.  The food was very unique and different.  But this was a good different.  We went for the Chef's selection which meant we didn't know what was coming but trusted that we would be happy.  As it  turned out the food was very good.  We were served 7 carefully prepared entrees.  The dishes are designed to be savored, internalized and then discussed.  That was part of the charm and allure.  Of course if it didn't taste good than then what would be the point?  I really liked the corn chowder?/soup and the home made Spam with eggs salad (guys from  Hawaii this is not your mother's Spam and egg). Fresh ingredients/creative taste combos. Tracy and her hard working husband/Chef, Shawn, has a good thing going here.  My wife and I will be back for their other entrees soon.
author: Dwight S.

description: After posting this review I got a call the next day from them given me a reservation even without my credit card!!! Why couldn't they do this before? So I upgraded them to 3 stars. At least they read the Yelp reviews. I didn't go since I already had a reservation to another restaurant in the mission district.
author: Benjamin P.

description: Whether you're looking for something new or want to reconnect with a cuisine that you really just can't find anywhere else around here, this place is a home run in almost every way. It has a bit of a "permanent pop-up" feel, which in my mind means chefs and restauranteurs doing what they love the way they want to do it. I'm not a chef, but it seems like a good way to connect with your passion and shed the restrictions placed on creativity by larger establishments.
